title: Taylor Swift and Travis Kelce‚Äôs Complete Relationship Timeline
text:
Every item on this page was chosen by an ELLE editor. We may earn commission on some of the items you choose to buy.
It‚Äôs a love story that could actually be a Hollywood rom-com: The top American pop singer and the top American football player meet up, sparks fly, and they end up dating with the world watching. Taylor Swift and Kansas City Chiefs tight end Travis Kelce have dominated headlines since their romance was first rumored to be a thing, with Swift‚Äôs first appearance at Kelce‚Äôs game in Kansas City becoming one of the year‚Äôs most buzzed-about moments. 
While the two may not be official just yet, things are escalating quickly, and anything is possible in the future, sources have made clear.
Here, the full history of their relationship that is known so far.
Kelce plays ‚ÄúKiss, Marry, Kill‚Äù in an interview, with the choices being Ariana Grande, Katy Perry, and Taylor Swift. ‚ÄúDamn, that‚Äôs messed up. I don‚Äôt want to kill any of them,‚Äù he prefaced. He then answered, ‚ÄúAriana is kill, unfortunately. I love you, but you‚Äôre gone. And then Taylor Swift would be the kiss, and then Katy Perry would be the‚Äîwhat‚Äôs the last one? Katy Perry would be the marry.‚Äù The interview resurfaced in 2023 as the dating rumors with Swift began to gain traction.
Kelce discusses shooting his shot and missing while attending Swift‚Äôs Eras Tour show in Kansas City, Missouri on his New Heights podcast with his brother Jason, an NFL player for the Philadelphia Eagles. Kelce‚Äôs remarks get media pickup.
‚ÄúI was disappointed that she doesn‚Äôt talk before or after her shows because she has to save her voice for the 44 songs that she sings. So I was a little butthurt I didn‚Äôt get to hand her one of the bracelets I made for her,‚Äù Kelce said. ‚ÄúIf you‚Äôre up on Taylor Swift concerts, there are a friendship bracelets and I received a bunch of them being there, but I wanted to give Taylor Swift one with my number on it. All right now.‚Äù
Jason asked if his brother meant his jersey number or phone number. 
‚ÄúYou know which one,‚Äù Kelce answered. ‚ÄúShe doesn‚Äôt meet anybody and at least she didn‚Äôt want to meet me so I, um, I took that personal. But it was an unbelievable show and I‚Äôve only seen Arrowhead filled like that for Chiefs games with that much excitement, and yeah, everybody was dressed in pink and purple going crazy. It was a wild show.‚Äù
Swift and Kelce‚Äôs romance takes off this month. Here‚Äôs the play-by-play (pun very much intended).
Swift goes out in New York City, wearing Foundrae‚Äôs Forever & Always a Pair Pendant, which has an opal teardrop stone on it. Fans note later that opal is Kelce‚Äôs birth stone (he is a Libra), and the necklace may have been an easter egg.
The Messenger reports that Swift and Kelce have been spending time together. ‚ÄúTaylor and Travis have been quietly hanging out,‚Äù a source told the outlet. ‚ÄúShe saw him when she was in NYC a few weeks ago.‚Äù
That same day, another source told Entertainment Tonight that Kelce isn‚Äôt Swift‚Äôs secret new boyfriend: They are ‚Äúnot officially dating.‚Äù Sources will continue to stress this in the coming weeks.
Kelce‚Äôs brother Jason adds fuel to dating rumors during his appearance on the TNF Nightcap‚Äôs post-game interview.
‚ÄúI‚Äôve seen these rumors‚Ä¶I cannot comment,‚Äù he said, noting that ‚Äúever since Catching Kelce [Kelce‚Äôs 2016 E! dating series], everyone‚Äôs been infatuated with Travis‚Äô love life, so, I don‚Äôt really know what‚Äôs going on there. I know Trav is having fun, we‚Äôll see what happens with whoever he ends up with.‚Äù
Tony asked Jason about the Travis Kelce and Taylor Swift dating rumors üòÇ@TonyGonzalez88 | #TNFonPrime pic.twitter.com/iHHqDvWC9B
That same day, Kelce dodges questions about Swift during an interview with Andrew Siciliano. 
‚ÄúI‚Äôm not gonna talk about my personal life,‚Äù Kelce said. ‚ÄúI know what you writers wanna hear, and you wanna hear more about that, and I‚Äôm not gonna give you anything.‚Äù
Jason jokingly confirms the Taylor-Travis dating rumors on Audacy‚Äôs SportsRadio 94 WIP. When asked about the gossip surrounding his brother and Swift, Jason said that ‚Äúit‚Äôs hard to answer because I don‚Äôt really know a lot about Travis‚Äô love life. I try to keep his business kind of his business, stay out of that world. But having said that, I think he‚Äôs doing great, and I think it‚Äôs all 100 percent true, and I hope this thing goes a mile.‚Äù Then he made it clear he was just kidding: ‚ÄúNo, I‚Äôm joking, I don‚Äôt know what's happening.‚Äù
The Messenger also gets more intel on the relationship from Swift‚Äôs side that day.
‚ÄúShe and Travis have hung out twice, and it‚Äôs nothing serious,‚Äù the source said. ‚ÄúShe thinks he is very charming, and they have been texting this last week. He is a little embarrassed at how much attention they are getting, but he has told her he would love to continue seeing her.‚Äù
‚ÄúThey are seeing where things go,‚Äù the source added, noting that Swift‚Äôs ‚Äúfriends are always playfully suggesting people to set her up with. [She‚Äôs] in her fun girl era and strictly having fun right now.‚Äù
Kelce says he invited Swift to his game during an interview with The Pat McAfee Show. She later does attend it.
 ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs hilarious how much traction this has actually gotten, right now it‚Äôs like a game of telephone,‚Äù Kelce said of the dating rumors. ‚ÄúNo one actually knows what‚Äôs going on, especially when you got [my brother] Jason Kelce on live television telling people both sides‚Äîhe doesn‚Äôt know, it‚Äôs true, this and that.‚Äù 
Regarding his status with Swift, Travis gave a frank answer: ‚ÄúI threw it out there, I threw the ball in her court. I told her, you know, I‚Äôve seen you rock the stage in Arrowhead [Stadium], you might have to come see me rock the stage in Arrowhead and see which one‚Äôs a little more lit. So, we‚Äôll see what happens in the near future.‚Äù
A source close to the situation tells E! that Swift and Kelce have no plans to see each other imminently, downplaying their closeness. 
‚Äú[They] met up once in New York,‚Äù the source said. ‚ÄúThey‚Äôve been texting and talking here and there but [have] no set plans to see each other again. It‚Äôs been very low-key as he‚Äôs been in season.‚Äù Obviously, that changes two days later.
Swift takes up Kelce‚Äôs invitation and attends his game in Kansas City. She is photographed in the stands with his mom. Sources reveal later that it was her first time meeting his family, and it went well.
Swift and Kelce are filmed leaving the game, marking the first video of them together.
Daily Mail later reveals that Swift met Kelce‚Äôs friends and family at his home before going to the game. The outlet wrote that she spent an hour with them before boarding a party bus with them to the stadium. 
A source told Daily Mail, ‚ÄúTravis wasn‚Äôt at his house, but it was filled with his friends and family. He has a personal chef and several friends from high school and college who use his place as a crash pad whenever they are in town.‚Äù
A source told People that day that, once again, Swift and Travis aren‚Äôt serious, but she was happy to see him play. 
‚ÄúTaylor is very focused on work right now and hanging out with her girlfriends. Travis invited her to the game, and of course she said ‚Äòyes,‚Äô‚Äù the source said. ‚ÄúShe just thought it was a fantastic way to spend Sunday.‚Äù
A source later added to People that ‚Äúthey‚Äôre having fun. This was Taylor‚Äôs first time meeting his mom and dad, and everyone was enjoying themselves. She was super chill and low-key hanging out with his friends and family.‚Äù
Kelce and Swift end their day celebrating with his teammates and family at Prime Social Rooftop. They get affectionate there.
Outlets get more information on the post-game date. 
Initial reports claim that Swift and Kelce paid to rent out Prime Social Rooftop. In reality, they had a reservation.
An eyewitness told Entertainment Tonight, ‚ÄúTravis bought out the restaurant for his family and team. Taylor arrived, wearing a denim dress, and was seen snacking, having some cocktails and dancing alongside Travis. The two were very affectionate with one another but kept things fun and lighthearted. Travis‚Äô teammates also showed up to the after-party, as well as his mom, Donna Kelce. The party lasted until 2 A.M.‚Äù
TMZ was also told that Swift and Kelce were affectionate at the game‚Äôs after-party. ‚ÄúSources say they were holding hands at the restaurant he rented out for his family, friends, and teammates after the game. At one point Taylor was sitting on Travis‚Äô lap,‚Äù TMZ wrote.
In addition, multiple sources discuss Swift and Kelce‚Äôs current relationship status.
TMZ was told by sources that Swift and Kelce‚Äôs relationship is not a publicity stunt, first of all. The sources shared that Swift and Kelce have seen each other ‚Äúseveral times‚Äù over the last few months, but are not officially dating yet. Previous in-person meetings have been in a ‚Äúvery private setting,‚Äù per the sources.
Entertainment Tonight‚Äôs insiders said that things between Swift and Kelce remain casual, but he has potential to be a good match for her. Swift specifically liked that he pursued her.
‚ÄúTravis has never shied away from his desire to give dating with Taylor a try, which he even said during a press conference a few months ago after seeing Swift in concert,‚Äù one source said. ‚ÄúTravis and Taylor are taking things slowly and not rushing into anything serious. Both are very career-focused, so the focus is on that for now, but that‚Äôs not going to stop them from enjoying life when it‚Äôs the right moment.‚Äù
A second source added that ‚ÄúTravis and Taylor have a lot in common and they are having a great time getting to know each other. They have similar values. She likes that he pursued her and it has been easy and exciting for both of them.‚Äù
‚ÄúTaylor is enjoying some time off from touring and it‚Äôs been fun hanging out with Travis during this break,‚Äù the source continued. ‚ÄúTaylor wants a guy that‚Äôs into his career, does his own thing, but is also supportive and understands her, and Travis fits those qualities.‚Äù 
Last of all, a source told People that Swift and Kelce‚Äôs romance is in the ‚Äúsuper, super early days.‚Äù That source added of their future, ‚ÄúThey‚Äôre just hanging out, and there‚Äôs no pressure.‚Äù
Swift is seen arriving at the airport in Kansas City around 10:30 A.M. to fly back home. Daily Mail reported that security vehicles were seen parked on Kelce‚Äôs street on Sunday and Monday nights in a clear sign that the two stars spent some private time together post-game.
Multiple sources speak to Us Weekly that day about Swift and Kelce‚Äôs relationship. Once again, they say it‚Äôs not serious.
One Us Weekly source said that Swift met Kelce through a mutual friend: ‚ÄúThey have been on a few dates, and Taylor is smitten with him. It is not serious, and Taylor is having fun right now.‚Äù
‚Äú[She‚Äôs] working hard right now and not looking for anything serious,‚Äù the source continued, citing her tour schedule and his NFL schedule as reasons why a more committed romance would be more difficult. ‚ÄúBut anything is possible. They‚Äôre getting closer and closer every day.‚Äù
Kelce speaks on his podcast New Heights for the first and maybe last time about his relationship with Swift.
‚ÄúI know I brought all this attention to me, right?‚Äù Kelce started. ‚ÄúI did the whole friendship bracelet thing and told everyone how butt-hurt I was that I didn‚Äôt get to meet Taylor.‚Äù
At the same time, he has no any regrets. ‚ÄúYou miss 100 percent of [the shots] you don‚Äôt take, baby, so yeah,‚Äù he said, then adding, ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs real is it is my personal life, and I want to respect both of our lives. She‚Äôs not in the media as much as I am doing this show every single week and you know, having fun during the NFL season and on other guys‚Äô shows like the McAfee Show, and any other show that I go on from here on out.‚Äù
‚ÄúI‚Äôm enjoying life, and I sure as hell enjoyed this weekend so everything moving forward, I think me talking about sports‚Ä¶will kind of have to be where I keep it,‚Äù he said.
‚ÄúI‚Äôm on the roller coaster, the roller coaster of life,‚Äù Kelce added of the experience dating Swift. ‚ÄúYeah, I notice a few things [are different], like paparazzi outside my house.‚Äù
Kelce gave Swift two shout-outs on the program: ‚ÄúShout-out to Taylor for pulling up [to the Chiefs game],‚Äù he said first. ‚ÄúThat was pretty ballsy, that was pretty ballsy, yeah. I just thought it was awesome how everyone in the suite had nothing but great things about her, you know the friends and family. She looked amazing. Everybody was talking about her in a great light, and on top of that, the day went perfect for Chiefs fans, of course. We script it all, ladies and gentlemen. It was just impressive.‚Äù
Of the game generally, he said, ‚ÄúIt was definitely a game I‚Äôll remember. That‚Äôs for damn sure. And then we just slid off in the getaway car at the end.‚Äù
His second shout-out to Swift was simple: ‚ÄúShout-out to Taylor for coming through and seeing me rock the stage.‚Äù 
Later that day, TMZ runs the first photo of Swift and Kelce showing PDA from the post-game party.
After rumors emerge that Swift could be attending Kelce‚Äôs Kansas City Chiefs game against the New York Jets at New Jersey‚Äôs MetLife Stadium, a source confirms it to Entertainment Tonight. ‚ÄúTaylor Swift is planning on attending the Jets game this Sunday,‚Äù the source said.
A second source added, ‚ÄúThe Jets haven‚Äôt been notified specifically about Taylor coming to Sunday‚Äôs game, but are prepared to welcome her if she decides to come. Patrick Mahomes booked a suite for his family and friends and Taylor could be joining that suite.‚Äù
In a separate report, a different source told Entertainment Tonight that Swift wasn‚Äôt initially expecting much from her and Kelce‚Äôs time together, but things are changing. ‚ÄúWhen Taylor and Travis first connected, Taylor was looking to have fun while enjoying some downtime,‚Äù the source said. ‚ÄúSo far, it‚Äôs been a nice change of pace for her. Now, as things progress between Taylor and Travis, they‚Äôre both looking to keep it more private. They‚Äôre both excited about where things are headed.‚Äù 
The Daily Mail reports that the couple has allegedly discussed doing a Halloween costume together and potentially attending Heidi Klum‚Äôs famous Halloween party, a celeb-packed event. The ‚Äúinsider‚Äù said they joked about dressing as Barbie and Ken. 
That source gave more detail on their dynamic, claiming that ‚Äúthe whirlwind that this relationship has started is something that Taylor is familiar with, and Travis is okay with. He wants to get in as much time as possible with her before she embarks on her international tour.‚Äù
As rumored, Swift attends Kelce‚Äôs Sunday night game against the New York Jets at MetLife Stadium. She brings a pack of celeb friends including Blake Lively, Ryan Reynolds, Sophie Turner, Hugh Jackman, and Sabrina Carpenter.
Swift and Kelce aren‚Äôt photographed or filmed together during the game, truly keeping things more private. They left the stadium separately after the game. Page Six reported that Kelce was photographed leaving Swift‚Äôs apartment earlier in the day, although not because he spent the night Saturday. 
A source told Page Six that the two had a Sunday morning hangout, as Kelce adhered to his team‚Äôs 11 P.M. curfew on Saturday. He left Swift‚Äôs apartment around 11 A.M.
After the game, Swift went to Zero Bond with her brother Austin Swift and his girlfriend Sydney Ness. Kelce was not photographed there with her.
Multiple sources tell People that Swift and Kelce‚Äôs relationship is undefined.
‚Äú[They‚Äôre] still just getting to know each other,‚Äù the first source said. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs nothing too serious.‚Äù
A second source added that their relationship is casual and unlabeled: ‚ÄúHe is a charming guy. It‚Äôs more of a hanging out situation than dating,‚Äù that source said. They added that while Kelce is spending time with Swift, ‚Äúhe‚Äôs focusing on football like he always has. During the NFL season, his priority is the Chiefs, and it‚Äôs all about the team.‚Äù
Sources speak to Us Weekly about Swift‚Äôs feelings for Kelce and how her approach to their romance is differing from hers with ex-boyfriend Joe Alwyn. 
‚ÄúTaylor has decided she‚Äôs not going to hide anymore,‚Äù one source said. ‚ÄúShe‚Äôs going to be her authentic self and enjoy life.‚Äù
Kelce and Swift ‚Äútalk every day,‚Äù the source added. ‚ÄúTaylor‚Äôs really enjoying getting to know Travis. They‚Äôre taking it day by day, but she has high hopes. She likes that he‚Äôs a normal, nice guy. He‚Äôs down-to-earth and isn‚Äôt affected by fame. She also thinks he‚Äôs hot.‚Äù
A second source said Kelce feels similarly: ‚ÄúTravis is completely smitten.‚Äù
A third source said, ‚ÄúTaylor is at a point in her life where she‚Äôs no longer willing to hold back. If something feels right‚Äîlike it does with Travis‚Äîshe‚Äôs jumping in with both feet. She‚Äôs very happy and loving life right now.‚Äù
Kelce, meanwhile, discusses how he wasn‚Äôt expecting his relationship with Swift to blow up the way it did during his appearance on Chasin‚Äô It with Trey Wingo and Chase Daniel. ‚ÄúI had no idea, man,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúI had no idea. You can‚Äôt tell me that anybody else did either, but I can‚Äôt be mad at how it‚Äôs all played out. I‚Äôll say that.‚Äù
Swift is seen leaving New York City the day before Kelce‚Äôs birthday, sparking rumors she may be traveling to spend the day with him. 
Kelce, meanwhile, spoke about the attention his romance with Swift has gotten from the NFL during his New Heights podcast. ‚ÄúThey‚Äôre overdoing it a little bit, for sure,‚Äù he said of their promotion. ‚ÄúEspecially my situation [with Swift]. I think they‚Äôre just trying to have fun with it.‚Äù
After Kelce‚Äôs remarks go viral, the NFL defends their social media approach. ‚ÄúWe frequently change our bios and profile imagery based on what‚Äôs happening in and around our games, as well as culturally,‚Äù the organization tells People. ‚ÄúThe Taylor Swift and Travis Kelce news has been a pop cultural moment we‚Äôve leaned into in real time, as it‚Äôs an intersection of sport and entertainment, and we‚Äôve seen an incredible amount of positivity around the sport.‚Äù

The poet-turned-novelist talks death, the divine, and getting lost in the desert.
Writing her latest novel almost killed Melissa Broder‚Äîor, anyway, that‚Äôs how it seemed when the Milk Fed and So Sad Today author realized she was lost during a solo hike at Death Valley National Park‚Äôs Zabriskie Point. The Los Angeles-based Broder had come to this trail to research what would eventually become her third novel, Death Valley. How she ended up lost in ‚Äúthe most touristy area‚Äù under the hot April sun with no cell reception, no water, and a bottle of Diet Coke, was thanks to both misdirection and tragedy. 
In December 2020, Broder‚Äôs father was in a car accident, and his resulting injuries required a months-long stay in the intensive care unit. Living on the other side of the country and unable to visit him due to the hospital‚Äôs COVID precautions, Broder spent hours driving back and forth between her home in Los Angeles and her sister‚Äôs in Las Vegas, ‚Äútrying to escape a feeling.‚Äù 
‚ÄúI was driving through Baker, [California], which is approximately where the fictional town [in the novel] would be, and the first line of the novel came to me,‚Äù Broder says. (The book starts: ‚ÄúI pull into the desert town at sunset feeling empty.‚Äù) ‚ÄúI was like, ‚ÄòOK, this is it.‚Äô I was working on another novel, and I put it down and started writing this.‚Äù
This epiphany led to her taking a ‚Äúdesert recon trip‚Äù to research Death Valley for her book, where she roamed astray around Zabriskie Point, panicked and cut-up from climbing rocks to find her way. Around 40 minutes after becoming lost, Broder found her way back to her car. ‚ÄúWhen I got out, I was like, ‚ÄòThis is a gift.‚Äô‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúNow I know what‚Äôs going to happen in my novel.‚Äù
In Death Valley, a woman drives to a small desert town under the pretense of researching a book‚Äîthough, underneath the guise of work, she‚Äôs running from feelings of emptiness and doom caused by a chronically ill husband and her injured father in the ICU. But when what‚Äôs supposed to be a casual hike turns perilous, the woman encounters a giant cactus, talking rocks, and a huge mustachioed oriole over the course of her multi-day fight for survival. Death Valley, even more than Broder‚Äôs past novels, makes powerful use of poetic diction and lyricism as the narrator works to orient herself‚Äîboth in a physical and emotional sense‚Äîto the terrain, the new reality of her ‚Äúprobably dying‚Äù father, and the nearly decade-long constant of her sick husband.
After six months in the ICU, and one month after her desert misadventure, Broder‚Äôs father died. Now, two and a half years later, Broder sat down with us to discuss why writing this novel felt like such an essential homage to him. 
My father died over a year before I finished the book. When I finished the book, I had a new experience with grief because the book had been a real connection with him. The day that I sent it off to my agent, I was like, ‚ÄúOh, he‚Äôs not coming back.‚Äù 
There was a lot of similarity. The first few months he was in the ICU, we weren‚Äôt allowed to see him because of COVID. I didn‚Äôt want to make the book a COVID narrative, but I felt like the distance was really important, the separation and the FaceTime. Because when my father was in and out of consciousness, my sister and I would just talk to him on FaceTime. But there would be times when he didn‚Äôt want to talk to anyone. He was fighting for his life. And that was a new learning curve: to not take someone‚Äôs ill health personally, and that we have to let people die in their own way and that it isn‚Äôt personal.
With this book, and actually with a lot of my writing, I can‚Äôt not do it. Writing this book almost killed me, but also not writing it would have almost killed me. I just had to do it. It‚Äôs really like, cows make milk; writers write. It‚Äôs how I orient myself to the world. It‚Äôs how I exist and survive in the world. 
There‚Äôs a big difference between writing and editing and publishing. The publishing is more challenging in terms of my perception of the reader. In my writing process, I just go. I try to dismantle any perfectionism and any voices, because otherwise I‚Äôll never write about anything. Editing is when I start to think about clarity, lucidity. 
The publishing is like closing your eyes and jumping into a pool. I can definitely feel, years after a book comes out, very invaded by something I put out in the world. Like, my 80-year-old Aunt Judy tells me she read So Sad Today and I feel invaded. But it‚Äôs like, I put it out there!
What was fun about this book is that it‚Äôs totally a sendup of autofiction. Obviously there‚Äôs a lot of differences, but someone could read it and say, ‚ÄúOh, the narrator is the author.‚Äù Then you start to get further and you‚Äôre like, ‚ÄúUm, did the author go into a magic cactus?‚Äù Probably no. That was really fun to do because people are always trying to figure out in novels, ‚ÄúDid this really happen?‚Äù Even when I was recording the audiobook, the audio engineer was like, ‚ÄúIs this a true story?‚Äù
I don‚Äôt, intellectually, believe that you have to suffer to make art. And even for myself, in a theoretical sense. I would love nothing else more than not to suffer. There‚Äôs nothing I would love more, truly. And perhaps a lot of my suffering‚Äîand I address this in this book‚Äîis caused by a desire of wanting to be at peace. The human experience will have its ups and downs. The alchemy of writing is a way to bring in light and creativity and, in a way, a higher power‚Äîif a higher power is (and it is for me) a creative force and not a destructive force.
When she has the vision of the bird, she‚Äôs so convinced that her father is dead. That‚Äôs a projection of her own experience, however mystical, however divine. I do have a relationship with signs and certainly with a higher power, but I believe that what we believe exists if we choose to believe that it exists. But we can‚Äôt project that on other people; faith only goes as far as ourselves. I think it was another lesson for her. Her interpretations and the way she perceived catastrophe were her own projection‚Äîit was something coming from herself. And that, to me, was really strong. 
My father was very funny, very dry, very sarcastic. So a book that is my homage to him has to be funny. And I have to have a good time when I‚Äôm writing, especially prose, because it‚Äôs such a marathon.
I feel the same way about incorporating humor as I do with sex scenes. When I write sex scenes, I have to turn myself on. If I don‚Äôt turn myself on, there‚Äôs no way I‚Äôm going to turn on the reader. It‚Äôs the same with humor in the sense of, you can feel when you read a book that the writer is having a good time writing it. And I think there‚Äôs something really beautiful about that. 
Life and death are also funny in their strangeness. It‚Äôs hilarious that we exist and it‚Äôs hilarious that we have to die. Both are really dark, but also really funny. 
I did a bunch, dictating, and then I scrapped the whole thing and started again. This was the first piece of prose that I‚Äôve written by typing. I usually don‚Äôt edit that hard in my first few drafts‚Äîit‚Äôs mostly getting the clay out. But with this, because it was for my dad, I wanted it to be a diamond every step of the way. 
I realized dictation wouldn‚Äôt work; I edited this like I edit a poem, with the intensity and care. There‚Äôs a risk to editing on a sentence level that precisely early on, because, if the structure doesn‚Äôt work, a lot of those sentences are going to be thrown away. But I wanted whatever was on the page to be beautiful.
This conversation has been edited and condensed for clarity.
Claudia Guthrie is a freelance writer based in Denver. When she's not writing about food or pop culture, she's probably listening to the latest true-crime podcast or binge-watching a Mike Flanagan Netflix series for the third time.

title: Inside the S√©zane Tote Black Market
text:
Every item on this page was chosen by an ELLE editor. We may earn commission on some of the items you choose to buy.
The free totes that come with each purchase from the French fashion brand have become so covetable there‚Äôs a burgeoning resale community.
In Paris, it‚Äôs nearly impossible to go within a one-mile radius without spotting a S√©zane tote bag. The fashion brand, founded by Morgane S√©zalory in 2013, is sort of like the French girl‚Äôs Madewell: ubiquitous, utilitarian, but undoubtedly trendy. Like French style, its wares are slightly more feminine‚Äîthink: bows and florals and lady-like brocade sandals in colors like gold and rosy beige. Though S√©zane began as an e-commerce enterprise, it has since expanded into brick-and-mortar locations, and each store is designed to feel like your chicest friend‚Äôs apartment on the Left Bank (not unlike S√©zalory‚Äôs own home, recently profiled in Architectural Digest). Perhaps the most memorable part of a S√©zane shopping experience is the free tote bag you get to carry your purchases in, which can instantly become as crucial a part of your style rotation as the clothes and accessories that fit inside it. 
Fifteen years ago, when S√©zalory was first starting the brand, she wanted to find a way to provide each shopper with a memento‚Äîa small token that felt unique. Eventually, she decided on a tote bag. A sustainable linen bag could replace the plastic bags used in French grocery stores at the time, while also serving as valuable real estate space for marketing. ‚ÄúI was thinking, okay, Paris is small, so if you have something that is very visual, and all the girls have it‚Ä¶if you don‚Äôt know the brand and you see someone wearing something very cool a few times in the same week, at some point you‚Äôre going to think: what is that? And then you look and you end up on the website,‚Äù S√©zalory told ELLE.com. 
The idea worked‚Äîand a decade and a half later, it‚Äôs still working. S√©zane fans are unequivocally obsessed with these tote bags. They collect them Facebook groups, on Mercari and French classified ads website Leboncoin, with offers to sell, buy, and trade the free totes. These ‚ÄúS√©zane Addicts,‚Äù or ‚ÄúS√©zanettes,‚Äù as they call themselves, are more than 72K strong‚Äîand that‚Äôs just on Facebook. For limited-edition tote bags, especially those that are part of a special collab like the one the brand recently did with Farm Rio, users will offer cash or a trade to get their bag of choice. ‚ÄúHello, I‚Äôm throwing a bottle to the sea: I fell in love with this tote bag Farm Rio collab but would like to buy it at a reasonable price (15 to 20 euros). If anyone wants to help me?‚Äù reads one recent post by a woman named Sandra. (Good luck to Sandra, as that tote, of which S√©zane made limited runs, is selling on Vestiaire Collective for more than 135 euros.)
In fact, sites like Vestiaire Collective, Poshmark, The RealReal and Mercari are full of people hawking the free S√©zane tote bags they got for upwards of 20, 30, even 100 euros. That Farm Rio bag that Sandra‚Äôs on the hunt for was the most expensive one we spotted, but others, like this banana-themed one, were selling for 87 euros, and this one‚Äîwhich I actually have two of and had no idea until now it was valuable!‚Äîis ‚Äúon sale‚Äù on The RealReal for 92 Euros.
Kimberley Blanchot, one half of the sister duo behind the French-American PR agency August 28 Studio, is one such avid collector (and, full disclosure, a good friend). On a recent trip to her apartment in Neuilly, she opened a cupboard to reveal several shelves packed with dozens of neatly folded tote bags. Though there were ones from brands her firm reps and others she‚Äôd collected in New York, the S√©zane pile was the most prolific: this woman, and I am not exaggerating, had 20 S√©zane tote bags, and with each one she had a little excuse for keeping it: ‚ÄúThis one‚Äôs great for the beach; I use this one a lot to carry my computer.‚Äù
‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt really set out to collect them, I was just an avid S√©zane follower and got one every time I shopped there,‚Äù Blanchot said. ‚Äú I was living in New York at the time and the brand wasn‚Äôt international yet, so there was a bit of a cool factor‚ÄîI liked that each collection gave life to a new design collab so just naturally started to accumulate them and now here we are.‚Äù 
Blanchot isn‚Äôt alone. ‚ÄúIt started when I became a VIP customer, I received a tote bag as a gift, then during certain orders, I also received free tote bags, and little by little my collection grew,‚Äù said Tatiana, a 31-year-old pediatric nurse from Lille. ‚ÄúToday I have 25 tote bags. They are so beautiful and all different, and I continue my little tote bag hunt to unearth rare pearls.‚Äù
As the bags have grown in popularity, S√©zane has begun partnering with others to package and advertise wares together. One recent summer collab featured the French issue of Vanity Fair packaged with a yellow and white striped beach tote; another advertised the gelato brand Amorino. 
The fact that she started an ongoing Parisian-wide trend doesn‚Äôt seem to faze S√©zalory, who says she spots the totes around Paris all the time but doesn‚Äôt ‚Äúinternalize it.‚Äù She recently had her third child, so her own collection of totes has been repurposed. ‚ÄúThe quality of [the bags] is great,‚Äù S√©zalory said. ‚ÄúI put my diapers in it‚Äîmy S√©zane tote is my baby bag.‚Äù
Jessica Roy is the former Digital Director of ELLE.com. Prior to that, she worked as the News Editor of The Cut. She likes baking, running, and Instagrams of your dog.

title: Life as El Chapo‚Äôs Wife
text:
The real story of Emma Coronel Aispuro.
Emma Coronel Aispuro looked straight into the camera as the sheriff‚Äôs deputy booked her into the Alexandria Sheriff‚Äôs Office in Virginia: shadows pooling across her full lips, dark circles ringing her eyes, and her dark hair, parted at the center, falling over her denim blue and green prison shirt. In the mug shot law enforcement dispatched to international media, announcing the capture of El Chapo‚Äôs wife, Emma looked as she felt: tired but resolute. 
Her Feb. 22, 2021, arrest was an anniversary of sorts: foreshadowed seven years before on the exact same day when Mexican marines escorted her husband in handcuffs, after having apprehended him in a Mazatl√°n apartment where they were staying with their twin daughters. Within days of her own arrest, media rumors would swirl that the 31-year-old was cooperating with federal agents. As she sat in her cell, she‚Äôd worry about her family back home and what the future might hold for her. Because she had known this day would come. The present had finally caught up to the hypothetical: She, too, was going down for her husband‚Äôs crimes.
The Casanova Cantina in Culiac√°n, a city in northwestern Mexico where Emma had moved after marrying one of the world‚Äôs most notorious drug lords on her 18th birthday, was packed. Hundreds of young people danced to blaring reggaet√≥n, and the drinks were flowing. Servers carried flaming trays shaped like life-size flamingos and gigantic American Express cards, delivering bottles of champagne and drinks in brightly colored glasses. 
The cantina was known for attracting buchonas, women with surgically enhanced curves. Tonight, there were murmurs that a niece of Joaqu√≠n Guzm√°n Loera‚ÄîEl Chapo himself, imprisoned for life en el otro lado (in the United States)‚Äîwas there ahorita mismo. This very moment! Julio C√©sar Ch√°vez Jr., the famous Mexican boxer married to the widow of Chapo‚Äôs assassinated son, roamed the crowded room.
Nearby, young women were deep in discussion about a hot topic in Culiac√°n: the impending sentencing of Emma Coronel Aispuro, due in a few days in a courthouse in Washington, D.C. Emma was a celebrity here. El Chapo had plucked her from a beauty pageant some 14 years before, when she was just 17, selecting her as his wife. As the leader of one of the world‚Äôs most prolific drug cartels, he could do that. Now, with Emma facing punishment for helping her husband and the cartel, everyone had an opinion.
‚ÄúHonestly, I don‚Äôt think it‚Äôs fair, because she isn‚Äôt directly involved,‚Äù Karla Castro said in Spanish of Emma‚Äôs incarceration. ‚ÄúWe have to consider that she‚Äôs a mom, and, as his wife, remained silent about what her husband was doing.‚Äù 
‚ÄúI believe that more than anything, she did it for her kids,‚Äù added Iskra Burgue√±o, another patron of the club. She was referring to Emma traveling to the United States earlier that year, where she was almost guaranteed to be arrested.
The women shook their heads, wondering aloud whether the brazo largo (‚Äúlong arm‚Äù) of the U.S. government was reaching too far into their country under the guise of protecting American citizens from deadly narcotics.
To some, Emma was a victim of the cartel who had no choice but to do what she was told, including breaking the law. To others, she was a victim of overzealous U.S. prosecutors eager to make an example of her, likely knowing she couldn‚Äôt cut a deal with the U.S. government without worrying about the worst kinds of consequences from the cartel if she ever returned to her homeland. And to others still, she wasn‚Äôt a victim at all, but rather a grown woman who made it rich through her looks and contribution to an international drug syndicate.
‚ÄúOnce you enter, how do you leave that world?‚Äù Castro said, first in Spanish, then in English. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs all she knows.‚Äù
‚ÄúIt‚Äôs very difficult to leave that,‚Äù Burgue√±o said. ‚ÄúSo, I believe that more than anything, she‚Äî‚Äù
‚ÄúShe‚Äôs scared,‚Äù Castro interrupted.
‚ÄúI think she‚Äôs afraid of losing her family more than anything,‚Äù Burgue√±o said, nodding. 
After covering El Chapo‚Äôs trial for the New York Times, I traveled twice to Mexico, trying to make sense of his wife‚Äîand her life and marriage. Emma was arrested in February 2021 on drug trafficking charges, accused of passing communications between her husband and four of his sons to help her drug-lord husband escape from prison. She even knew of the plan to slip him a GPS device, with her youngest brother helping him escape through a tunnel. She chose to do these things. But considering she is a product of the machismo culture of the cartel, she arguably never had a choice.
And yet, she never claimed victimization. She came from a culture in which women can become the most tragic kind of victim: one who doesn‚Äôt know she‚Äôs being used at all.
Emma pleaded guilty to all three counts she was charged with, waiving her right to a trial, and was released from U.S. custody in Los Angeles County on September 13 of this year, after serving about two and a half years. (She will have four years of supervised release.) She did what she did willfully. But does a woman in her situation, married at 18 to a powerful killer three times her age, truly have a will to speak of? 
Tucked into the folds of the Sierra Madre Occidental mountains and rimmed in verdant green foliage, the town of Canelas glowed honey-lemon in the winter sunlight. A few weeks before the annual festival known as La Feria del Caf√© y la Guayaba, named for the region‚Äôs beloved coffee and guava, Emma, then a girl of 17, was campaigning against four other girls to be crowned that year‚Äôs reina‚Äîthe queen of the festival in a town of about 800 people.
Emma‚Äôs was no ordinary family‚Äîher father, In√©s Coronel Barreras, worked for the Sinaloa cartel, along with some other family members. Although the truth was that while her family was particularly enmeshed, in the area where she grew up, a cartel connection made them more ordinary than unusual.
Around 20 small planes and helicopters flew in guests for a Three Kings Day dance in honor of Emma‚Äôs candidacy. The winding, mountainous streets were crawling with horses, motorcycles, Hummers, and other expensive cars carrying la gente m√°s importante‚Äîfrom prominent traffickers to local politicians, including a member of the Federal Police‚Äîinto the small pueblo. One plane carried a man whose reputation and deadly reign as a leader of the Sinaloa cartel had made him one of the most wanted men in the world, and years later would prompt the U.S. State Department to offer a bounty of up to $5 million for his capture: Joaqu√≠n Guzm√°n Loera, better known as El Chapo. Another carried Ignacio ‚ÄúNacho‚Äù Coronel Villareal, a powerful cartel leader who oversaw its meth business. 
Emma was dating a local boy from the ranch‚Äîher first boyfriend. But she was ‚Äúvery serious, very centered, not much of a dating type,‚Äù her cousin, Alfonso L√≥pez, who lived near Emma‚Äôs family for much of their childhood, recalled in a November 2021 WhatsApp interview from his jail cell in the neighboring state of Sinaloa, where he was serving a sentence for illegally importing military weapons.
Emma knew Chapo the way any teenager might ‚Äúknow‚Äù someone famous. She had first caught his eye when they were introduced at a local dance in 2006, and she was aware of his wealth, his flashy, abundant lifestyle, his notoriety among drug lords. (Emma was 11 the first time he broke out of jail, in a laundry cart from one of Mexico‚Äôs most secure prisons.) Chapo was also a homeland hero, running a cartel many felt better supported the people and their public safety than the government itself. This was especially true in a town like Canelas, where girls and their families were often anxious for them to marry into financial security and safety. 
Chapo‚Äîwho, according to allegations that he raped girls as young as 13 and called young girls his ‚Äúvitamins‚Äù because they gave him ‚Äúlife‚Äù‚Äîwanted Emma. As the Three Kings Day dance got underway, he ordered the band to sing one of his favorite songs, ‚ÄúCruzando Cerros y Arroyos‚Äù (‚ÄúCrossing Hills and Streams‚Äù). ‚ÄúYou are a flower and you are beautiful,‚Äù the singers crooned. ‚ÄúYou are a perfumed rose and you were born for me.‚Äù When they finished, Chapo ordered it sung again. And again.
He and Emma talked for half an hour. Before leaving, Chapo gave Emma‚Äôs father a Chevy Cheyenne 4x4 and a Mercedes-Benz topped with a huge bow for Emma. In the mountains, where it‚Äôs still customary for families to be paid for their daughter‚Äôs hand, a kind of reverse dowry, Emma was now‚Äîquite suddenly‚Äîthe drug lord‚Äôs intended wife.
Two days later, 150 members of the 72nd Infantry Battalion descended on the area, searching for Chapo, having received intelligence that he was nearby. According to a local paper, over the next several weeks they stood guard over two airstrips and set up checkpoints on the road in between. But the battalion left just days before the feria‚Äîin time for Chapo to wend his way back to Canelas, and to Emma‚Äôs side.
A community newspaper article noted that Emma had enjoyed a ‚Äúgreat morbid popularity‚Äù in the days leading up to the Valentine‚Äôs Day election for queen. The competition was steep, Alfonso recalled. Acknowledging the other ‚Äúvery pretty candidates,‚Äù he said he suspected Chapo paid people off to vote for her.  
Among the honored guests on the day of the election was Chapo, who hired three bands to serenade Emma. Each opened with the same song, one after the other. ‚ÄúSe√±or Chapo paid a lot of money to make it a grand event,‚Äù Alfonso said. That feria was far grander, he believes, than any before or since.
Emma won the competition with exactly half of the 800 votes and was later crowned queen in a silky yellow dress, her hair in ringlets, her kohled eyes wide. 
On July 2‚Äîher 18th birthday‚Äîshe was married to Chapo, in what she described as a simple ceremony at her childhood home, surrounded by family and close friends, chickens clucking in the background. Emma wore a diamond-encrusted wedding dress, Chapo a black suit. For the next three days, bands and parties filled the streets of Canelas, ringed by la guardia, uniformed cartel members carrying automatic weapons.
The newlyweds escaped to the hill town of El Carrizo and a simple one-story wedding home: yellow with a terra-cotta roof, slender columns reaching up to wooden planks, a bare bulb hanging from the ceiling. Inside, Chapo and his teen bride waited out the authorities. Through the window there was a panoramic view of Canelas and the surrounding towns tumbled along the lonesome horizon. Alone with one of the most wanted men in the world, Emma was very much his‚Äîand only his.
After the wedding, Chapo moved Emma to a home in Culiac√°n, the cartel headquarters, population then around 630,000. She had grown up in a place even smaller than Canelas‚ÄîLa Angostura, with just a few dozen inhabitants‚Äîin the northwest state of Durango. Culiac√°n was a shock.
Emma was often alone while Chapo helped run the cartel‚Äîand, it was widely known, he was often with other women. She was just one in a never-ending conveyor belt of beautiful girls, with marriages that seemingly ran one into the next without the punctuation or officiality of divorce. Another of Chapo‚Äôs wives, Griselda L√≥pez P√©rez‚Äîwho was nearly three times Emma‚Äôs age‚Äîstill lived in Culiac√°n.
In those early years of her marriage, Emma began to change. Not in her demeanor, repeatedly described by family and residents of northwestern Mexico as simple and nice. But as her husband accumulated mistresses, the slight young girl shape-shifted into the full-bodied, tightly clad woman of her husband‚Äôs desires. 
Every time her cousin saw her, she was more transformed. Cosmetic surgeries are typical in the region, with women often remolding their faces and enlarging their breasts and butts. 
Then, when she was 21, Emma‚Äôs body changed in an entirely different way: She became pregnant. With twin girls.
As Chapo‚Äôs wife, Emma always felt safe. Untouchable. But her marriage to him assured protection only so long as he was still alive, a matter of whim in the narco world of shifting power dynamics. With Chapo still in power, she felt she and their children would be safe from the violence of the drug world. But if and, inevitably, when something happened to him, she feared she would be left unprotected. Emma wanted to give her future children at least a chance at some measure of lifelong safety. 
Emma was born near San Francisco, a dual American and Mexican citizen, with all the benefits and privileges American citizenship carried. And so, according to a 2011 Los Angeles Times article, nearing her due date and without her husband, Emma crossed the border into Southern California in July of that year, U.S. federal agents reportedly tracking her every move. Around a month later, she gave birth to daughters, born one minute apart at Antelope Valley Hospital in Los Angeles County: American citizens. Following her husband‚Äôs strict instructions, on their birth certificates Emma left blank the space for their father‚Äôs name, bestowing on them instead her own last name.
But she preserved their full parentage in their first names: Emali and Maria Joaqu√≠na. One for each parent. 
It was a lonely time. ‚ÄúAre you going to chat with me all day long or will you be busy?‚Äù Emma texted her husband just months after giving birth and preparing for a postpartum surgery. When the twins were six months old, Chapo narrowly escaped capture at a mansion in Los Cabos, Mexico. He and his secretary had escaped over a fence, cutting themselves on some nearby shrubbery. He told his wife about the arrests of two associates, but left out the third arrest of another mistress, Agustina Cabanillas Acosta. ‚ÄúA bit scratched up but fine, thank God,‚Äù he texted Emma‚Äîrelaying a similar message to another mistress, Lucero Guadalupe S√°nchez L√≥pez, who would later win a seat in the local legislature. 
In Mazatl√°n, Sinaloa, the entrance to the Miramar, a lemon-yellow seaside apartment complex, was guarded by a single employee. Above him were 11 stories, the balcony of each apartment etched with a single eye, eerily glinting at the soft, rolling waves of the Pacific.
Chapo, wearing sunglasses and slumped in a wheelchair‚Äîand just out of view of video cameras‚Äîwheeled through the residence in the darkness. Soon after, Emma slipped by the infinity pool and up to the fourth floor. Her twins and several attendants, whom a maintenance worker later told me had lived in the building without the parents on and off for months, were also in tow. Rounding a secluded corner by the staircase, she pushed open the paneled door of apartment 401 and joined her husband.
In the early morning hours, the couple jolted awake to the sound of Mexican and American law enforcement barreling through their front door and charging past the sleeping two-year-olds, guns drawn. 
This moment, Emma had always known, was inevitable. Chapo grabbed a Bushmaster semiautomatic rifle from his bedside table, leapt into the bathroom, and crouched inside, according to Alan Feuer, author of El Jefe: The Stalking of Chapo Guzm√°n.
‚ÄúDon‚Äôt kill him!‚Äù Emma screamed as law-enforcement authorities swarmed the couple‚Äôs bedroom. She glanced at the bathroom where her husband‚Äîher lifeline‚Äîwas hiding.
‚ÄúPlease, don‚Äôt kill him!‚Äù
With his wife pleading from the bed and their daughters nearby, Chapo surrendered without fire. ‚ÄúCalm down, I‚Äôm here,‚Äù Emma recalled her husband saying in an interview with the L.A. Times. Emma knew‚Äîshe had to know‚Äîin that moment that this was the beginning of the unraveling. Both her father and oldest brother had been arrested less than a year before. Many of the men in her life‚Äîthe very men who had pulled her into this world‚Äîwere leaving her. 
Chapo was incarcerated at Altiplano, a maximum-security prison. At least two women visited him there: Emma and Lucero (by now an elected official, visiting the prison using a fake ID). Both women also met‚Äîseparately‚Äîwith D√°maso L√≥pez Nu√±ez, a lieutenant in the Sinaloa cartel who had worked in the first prison Chapo escaped from when Emma was a child, and who was helping plan his boss‚Äôs second escape. Emma had meetings with L√≥pez Nu√±ez and Chapo‚Äôs sons to disseminate Chapo‚Äôs orders as he masterminded the getaway, L√≥pez Nu√±ez said later, including the plan to slip him a GPS device disguised as a food item, establishing the coordinates of the kingpin‚Äôs cell and the tunnel to be dug beneath it.
Chapo‚Äôs detainment was relatively short-lived. Just 504 days after his arrest, he dropped down a hole in his cell shower to a waiting makeshift motorcycle railcar, which he rode through a nearly mile-long tunnel dug under the prison to a warehouse. The escape plan had taken more than a year and approximately $1 million to execute. 
Emma‚Äôs youngest brother, √âdgar, a teenager, was allegedly waiting there in the tunnel to accompany his famous brother-in-law. Within hours, Chapo was taken to a clandestine airstrip, where he boarded a plane, and disappeared into the mountains. But he would spend that New Year‚Äôs Eve not with Emma but Lucero, celebrating the start of 2016 together.
Just eight days later, Chapo was captured yet again by Mexican authorities and extradited to New York, on six separate indictments filed in states across the country, including running a drug cartel and conspiring to push narcotics across the border. The charges carried a sentence greater even than his own life.
Inside Brooklyn federal court on Jan. 17, 2019, a guest star took the stand: Lucero Guadalupe S√°nchez L√≥pez. Dressed in a drab blue prison uniform, the only female cooperating witness to testify against the drug kingpin, Lucero had pleaded guilty to her part in his narco-trafficking conspiracy just months prior.
For all the world to hear, she referred to Chapo as ‚Äúmy husband, Joaqu√≠n.‚Äù The prosecution asked her to detail a years-long romance with the drug lord, which had started in the early days of Emma‚Äôs pregnancy. 
In a narco world in which power is measured in part by the number of girlfriends belonging to a capo, a loyal husband was more than Emma could have hoped for. But having his brazen infidelity internationally publicized must have felt humiliating.
Seated on a courtroom bench, separated by a divider from her husband, Emma, dressed in a black jacket over a white collared shirt, struggled to maintain her usual stoicism. Lucero spoke in Spanish, and Emma removed her translator headset, listening directly to the woman with whom she‚Äôd been sharing her husband.
The same age as Emma, with long, dark hair and almond eyes, Lucero, who grew up in a small Sinaloan town, had similar features and a similar background. But when she met Chapo at age 21, she was‚Äîunlike Emma‚Äînot burdened by the physical and emotional demands of pregnancy. Over two days of testimony that winter, Lucero detailed how she‚Äôd run Chapo‚Äôs money-laundering operations and overseen drug shipments secreted away on airplanes.
When Anthony Nardozzi, a prosecutor in El Chapo‚Äôs case, asked Lucero about the nature of her relationship to the kingpin, she answered: ‚ÄúWell, up until today I‚Äôm still confused, because I thought our relationship‚Äîwe were romantically involved as partners.‚Äù Emma bit her thumb.
And in a 2018 televised interview on Telemundo, Emma wondered aloud whether the media ‚Äúthink I‚Äôm not human or something,‚Äù given the way she felt the media objectified her. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm made of meat and bones.‚Äù
The day after Lucero began testifying, Emma took steps to more permanently secure her place in her husband‚Äôs narrative. She had a company registered: El Chapo Guzman JGL, LLC, the rights of which were placed in her name to start a clothing line.
When Emma returned to court for Lucero‚Äôs remaining testimony the following week, she and her husband dramatically appeared wearing matching maroon velvet jackets. Lucero, who‚Äôd broken down in guttural sobs while testifying, concluded her time on the stand facing a twinning couple. 
When Lucero finished, Emma paid an artist more than $1,600 for an exclusively drawn pastel rendering of her and her husband in their matching jackets. Per her explicit instructions, the other woman, in prison garb, was not included. 
Pulling off the mountain road, the SUV slashed down a dusty embankment to a white stone-filled creek and into the secluded town of La Angostura. Farther in, past a grove of grapefruit and lemon trees and tucked under the boughs of a towering orange tree, sat a pale yellow, one-story home roofed in terra-cotta.
The car pulled to a stop. A man with a gray mustache, white sombrero, and purple-trimmed hoodie slid from the passenger‚Äôs side, a puff of sandy dirt clouding his black loafers. This was Victorio Aredo Coronel, a nephew of Emma‚Äôs father. Victorio‚Äôs son, Gerardo Raudel Hern√°ndez Carrasco, popped out the back.
On the front porch, several children watched a flat-screen television, the din of a soccer game punctuated by the crowing shrieks of roosters waddling about the front yard.
Claudia Coronel, in her mid-twenties with a soft voice and long, dark hair, emerged from the house to greet her relatives. A long-ago portrait of her elder sister, Emma, smiled down at them from the porch: dark hooded eyes and plucked brows, with Emma wearing jeans and a mustard tube top, a cross necklace dangling from her neck.
I‚Äôd talked to Emma about going to her childhood home even before her husband‚Äôs trial ended. While everyone else in court studied her husband‚Äôs every move, I watched Emma, a woman about my age and yet so different. I wanted to better understand her life before her husband. 
No one will hurt you here: You‚Äôre safe, I was told when I arrived in Canelas. About 200 masked men with assault rifles ringed the town‚Äôs perimeter‚Äîla guardia, serving as guards for the annual coffee and guava festival.  
Now, outside Emma‚Äôs childhood home, where she‚Äôd lived until her marriage, Claudia greeted me with a kiss on the cheek: ‚ÄúI follow you on Instagram,‚Äù she said, smiling.
Blanca Estela Aispuro Aispuro‚Äîmother to four, including Emma and Claudia‚Äîstayed in the kitchen, preparing lunch. 
The family gathered in a room adjoining the kitchen, a tower of warm flour tortillas mounting through lunch, the fresh piled atop the cooling on an embroidered place mat. Passing a platter of fried bistec and spooning crumbly cotija cheese onto their plates, Emma‚Äôs family exchanged news from the recent feria and the crowning of this year‚Äôs queen.
Blanca asked about the festival‚Äôs official reina: Was she pretty?
From the other side of the table, Victorio nodded emphatically: Of course! The queen is always pretty, he said.
Gerardo hurried past photographs on his phone, stopping on one of the contestants in an aqua dress, gold-lettered sash, and soaring rhinestone tiara. 
Blanca hunched over the phone, considering. Then, after a while: ‚ÄúMy queen is prettier,‚Äù she said with a teasing smile.
With Chapo‚Äôs lifelong incarceration all but certain, Emma, for the first time as an adult, had to think about what her family‚Äôs life would look like without him. She made a guest appearance on VH1‚Äôs Cartel Crew in November 2019. She created an Instagram account, @therealemmacoronel. On it, she rarely mentioned her husband, instead documenting her own exploration of New York. She also continued experimenting with her hair: golden highlights for Mother‚Äôs Day 2020 and on her 31st birthday. By December, she had gone bleached blonde. Her hairstylist said later in an interview at his salon in Culiac√°n that Emma wanted to ‚Äúcambiar el look‚Äù‚Äîchange her look. She even posed in a fashion campaign for his salon, wearing a white lace wedding dress, rhinestones scattered down the pleats, a floral hair clip tucked into her long blonde locks.
In February 2021, just a few months later, she returned to the salon one last time, had her hair dyed back to its original color, and boarded a plane to Virginia for what one of her lawyers called a business trip. 
She was arrested at the airport.
Emma was charged with participating in a conspiracy led by her husband to import cocaine, methamphetamine, heroin, and marijuana into the United States. The complaint against Emma also noted that she had aided and abetted his now-infamous break from the high-security prison in Mexico via the tunnel‚Äîlikely a crime in Mexico, but not among the charges she faced in the U.S.
The conspiracy charge‚Äîa legal maneuver that can snag mobsters not easily caught in actual trafficking deals without requiring that they commit the offense themselves‚Äîis a wonderfully complicated legal construction. In Emma‚Äôs case, conspiring to import drugs was as inconsequential as passing text messages between her husband and father without ever actually touching drugs themselves. In open court, even the main prosecutor on her case called her a mere ‚Äúcog in a very large wheel of a powerful criminal organization‚Äù whose ‚Äúprimary significance on a criminal level‚Äù was her ‚Äúproximity‚Äù to her husband.
For the next 14 days, Emma was kept under strict COVID-19 protocols in a quarantine unit. When her period started shortly after her arrest, guards provided her with only two sanitary napkins for the next four days. She went just as long without a shower, the word becoming one of the first she learned in English, spelled out letter by letter by her Spanish-speaking lawyer so that Emma could repeat the request to guards in the hope of eventually getting one. In March of that same year, Emma was moved to solitary confinement. 
Snow flurries flitted against a slate-colored sky in Washington, DC. Inside a district courthouse on Constitution Avenue, a bomb-detection dog sniffed the courtroom. ‚ÄúEverything‚Äôs good,‚Äù the guard declared. Just after noon, flanked by U.S. marshals, Emma, who had been in U.S. custody for nine months, strode in, dressed in a fitted gold-buttoned black pantsuit and heels.
Appearing solemn behind her black mask, Emma took a seat at a table split by pandemic partitions and swiveled to face Judge Rudolph Contreras. When the judge invited her to speak, Emma adjusted the podium microphone and glanced at her approximately three-and-a-half-minute speech. ‚ÄúI know that you may find it difficult to ignore the fact that I am the wife of Joaqu√≠n Guzm√°n,‚Äù she said in Spanish, her voice softly strained. ‚ÄúAnd for perhaps‚Äî‚Äù 
The translator cut her off. Emma sighed and paused, continuing after her words were put into English for the judge: ‚ÄúFor this reason, you feel that there is a need for you to be harder on me. But I pray that you not do that.‚Äù She told the judge that her daughters, then 10 years old, were ‚Äúthe most important reason why I‚Äôm here before you,‚Äù adding she hoped to lead by example in encouraging them to own their mistakes: ‚ÄúI accept the mistakes that I have made and I am sorry for them.‚Äù 
Her voice cracked as she noted the pain she had put her family through. Her daughters might never have their father, she said, but ‚ÄúI beg you, please do not allow them to grow up without the presence of their mother.‚Äù 
Acknowledging the government‚Äôs higher sentencing guidelines for the crimes she committed, Judge Contreras, instead, described Emma‚Äôs involvement in Chapo‚Äôs operation as paling in comparison to that of other Sinaloa cartel members who had passed through his court, and sentenced her to three years behind bars with time served, and the forfeiture of $1.5 million. ‚ÄúGood luck to you,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúI hope that you raise your twins in a different environment than the one that you‚Äôve experienced.‚Äù
Fulfilling her sentence in a federal prison in Texas, Emma was transferred to Los Angeles County over the summer and then released. She‚Äôs 34‚Äîhalf a lifetime since first meeting El Chapo at that dance, when she caught the eye of a killer and the whole course of her life seemed preordained. 
Returning to her family in Mexico is almost out of the question. In a life with few choices, it turned out she may have made one that would ultimately matter most: seemingly turning a prison sentence into an escape route. 
And as Emma walked out of the courtroom on the afternoon of her sentencing, the end of one life promising the start of another, she turned briefly back to her supporters sitting in the audience‚Äîand winked.
‚ÄúI hope for many good and beautiful things in my life,‚Äù Emma would tell me later in her only interview since getting out of prison. She was feeling excited to be with her daughters again, and enjoying ‚Äúquality moments,‚Äù like when her family cooked steak for her upon her release. She said she was focused on her career plans, which are still evolving. ‚ÄúI still can‚Äôt say the plans, because then later they won‚Äôt come to be,‚Äù she added with a laugh. ‚ÄúBut many and beautiful.‚Äù
Credits: Emma Coronel Aispuro; lead image: Todd Heisler/Redux.
Emily Palmer is an investigative reporter, covering courts and crime. Her work has frequently appeared in The New York Times and Cosmopolitan, and her reporting has been featured on 20/20, Nightline, Max and Hulu. She joined People as a Senior Crime Writer in 2023.¬†

title: Taylor Swift Is Reportedly Supporting Sophie Turner ‚ÄòHowever She Can‚Äô Through Her Joe Jonas Divorce
text:
For Taylor Swift, lending one of her New York properties to Sophie Turner stems from a deep desire to be a true friend to Turner during her divorce from Joe Jonas. A source told Us Weekly that Swift ‚Äúinstinctively wanted to reach out‚Äù to Turner when she heard news of her and Jonas‚Äô split. 
Turner and Jonas are keeping their daughters in New York City as they work through their child custody case. Swift‚Äôs home is now Turner‚Äôs for the duration of the process. The singer is ‚Äúletting Sophie stay there as long as she needs and is supporting her however she can,‚Äù the source said.
In a separate story, a source told Us Weekly that ‚ÄúSophie is free to stay at Taylor‚Äôs investment property in NY until the custody case with Joe [Jonas] has been finalized.‚Äù
While Swift herself dated Jonas for a few months when she was 18, she is very much respecting boundaries now. Her priority is being there for Turner. 
‚Äú[She] doesn‚Äôt know all the details [of the divorce] because she doesn‚Äôt feel like it‚Äôs her place,‚Äù a source said on September 29. ‚ÄúAll she is concerned with is being there to support her friend.‚Äù
Turner and Jonas started mediation today for their custody case; it is slated to continue for four days. A source told People on September 28 that Turner ‚Äúis doing okay.‚Äù The source added, ‚ÄúTaylor has opened her home to Sophie. Sophie is welcome there any time. Taylor continues to be a great friend.‚Äù
While Turner hasn‚Äôt spoken about her friendship with Swift, the two have been photographed out together frequently. Notably, Turner was part of Swift‚Äôs squad at Travis Kelce‚Äôs Kansas City Chiefs game against the New York Jets on Sunday.

title: Zaya Wade Is Showing the World Who She Is
text:
Every item on this page was chosen by an ELLE editor. We may earn commission on some of the items you choose to buy.
A conversation with Miu Miu‚Äôs biggest muse during Paris Fashion Week.
Zaya Wade is finally old enough to get her driver‚Äôs license, but she‚Äôs been a driving force in the fashion industry for some time now.  The 16-year-old daughter of former NBA player Dwayne Wade and stepdaughter of actress Gabrielle Union has already walked runways, sat front row at fashion week, and posed on red carpets. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm having so much fun with fashion,‚Äù she tells ELLE.com.  
Since coming out as transgender in 2020, Wade says she has discovered the special‚Äîand uniquely affirming‚Äîtype of joy that comes with expressing yourself through what you wear. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a way to show the world that all the negativity isn‚Äôt going to bring me down,‚Äù she explains. ‚ÄúTo me, it‚Äôs about showing the world and myself that I‚Äôm just me. I‚Äôm still who I am and who I continue to want to be.‚Äù 
At Paris Fashion Week, Wade took in Miuccia Prada‚Äôs highly-anticipated spring 2024 collection wearing the brand‚Äôs leather harness biker boots, leather handbag, and a golden faux fur coat. After the show‚Äîand before heading out to the Miu Miu dinner party exclusively for editors, celebs, models, and stylists‚Äîwe caught up with Wade to talk about her foray into fashion.
ELLE: Tell me about getting ready for the Miu Miu show.
Zaya Wade: Well, in all honesty, I was a little nervous. I woke up very early this morning at 5 A.M., and couldn‚Äôt go back to bed. But it was the good kind of nervous. Then, I ate some breakfast. Glam came over round 11 A.M. It was really fun. It was low-key, but, you know, we wanted to slay, of course.
ELLE: Of course! What inspired your glam look? 
ZW: For the most part, I like to keep it very like clean, just neutral. But today, for the lip, we really wanted to do a lip line and go more bold with it. I wanted to bring some extra spice to the outfit, but there wasn‚Äôt a particular or specific inspiration‚Äîjust the energy that we decided to bring.
ELLE: Let‚Äôs talk about the outfit. How did you decide on what to wear? 
ZW: So it was very layered, all stuff from the new Miu Miu collection. Well, not the new collection, but you know, from the most recent collection. I had this faux fur coat, it was so chic and very warm. I wore these mid-calf boots. Oh my God, they are to die for. I‚Äôm like, can I keep them? 
ELLE: I‚Äôm manifesting that for you. 
ZW: Thanks! Then we filmed a lot of content [for social media], and by 12:30 P.M. we were on our way to the show. It‚Äôs been a day, a good day though. 
ELLE: You‚Äôve said in the past that fashion is a really important part of expressing yourself and expressing your identity.
ZW: Yes, growing up, my parents were both really, really fashionable. They always went out in some look, and I think that started it for me. It was so inspiring, because I feel like I am able to channel a lot of their energy and personality through clothes. Fashion is one of the most successful ways for me to express myself. I really wanted to get into the fashion world, because I‚Äôm not much of a painter. I was like, art is not for me‚Äîbut what I can do to express myself is wear a great outfit. I decided to get into this world and I‚Äôve been growing and learning and experimenting and trying to express myself every day through my clothing.
ELLE: And what have you learned so far?
ZW: I feel like the biggest thing I‚Äôve learned about the fashion industry so far is that there‚Äôs a lot more to it. Every single day I learn something new, but it‚Äôs so fun. I think a lot of people have preconceived notions about fashion and modeling, but at least to me it‚Äôs really fun. I mean, I get to go to Paris. Like, I‚Äôm here in Paris. I feel like everyone‚Äôs like, ‚ÄúOh, modeling, you‚Äôre just walking down the runway.‚Äù But it‚Äôs so much more than that. It‚Äôs an entire world. I still have so much to learn.
ELLE: What have you learned about yourself since getting into the fashion industry? 
ZW: My confidence has grown. I‚Äôve stepped into myself, especially starting out. I obviously came out as trans, and it was a very confusing time. I didn‚Äôt know everything about myself, but having that expression through clothing allowed me to come into my own. It gave me a level of confidence that I have needed and will probably need forever. It gave me the confidence to thrive.
ELLE: Do you think fashion can be used as a tool for communication? 
ZW: I always like to say that for me fashion is a form of expression. It‚Äôs a way to show the world that all the negativity isn‚Äôt going to bring me down. To me, it‚Äôs about showing the world and myself that I‚Äôm just me. I‚Äôm still who I am and who I continue to want to be.
ELLE: And who is that? 
ZW: I‚Äôm a lot of things. A really big part of me is my love for education and my strive to better the world in different ways. Obviously a big part of my life as a trans person is to be impactful in my community. I continue to take the question of ‚Äúwho am I?‚Äù and foster it and grow and, you know, evolve. Every day I ask myself, ‚ÄúWho am I?‚Äù And, like, how can I continue to move forward and better answer that question every single day?
ELLE: Speaking of evolvement and growth...in what ways do you think the fashion industry can continue to grow? 
ZW: Fashion has grown so much, and we‚Äôve obviously come so far. I would say most notably when it comes to gender fluidity and perceptions of sexuality and all these forms of expression, fashion is heading in the right direction. For too long, there was a very limited stance on what was worn and what was presented. Now, we‚Äôre breaking through that barrier and it‚Äôs [moving in the right direction]. 
ELLE: Which designers do you think are putting in the work to move the needle? 
ZW: There‚Äôs a world of brands out there doing great things, but Miu Miu really speaks to the image that I‚Äôd like to present to the world. Miu Miu is the moment. 
ELLE: Miu Miu is definitely the moment. What‚Äôs the best piece of fashion advice you‚Äôve gotten?
ZW: It hasn‚Äôt been a singular lesson. It‚Äôs more about how I carry myself with the clothes that I wear and less about the literal clothes that I wear. Because I think a lot of outfits can be pulled off with just attitude. My stepmom [Gabrielle Union] has given me that conversation about what confidence can do for you and how the clothes that you wear can help you get there. I think about that and embody that every time I put on an outfit. 
ELLE: What outfit makes you feel the most like yourself?
ZW: It‚Äôs kind of a mix. It really depends on the mood that I‚Äôm in, or what I‚Äôm feeling. Sometimes I‚Äôm here in sweatpants and a baggy sweatshirt and I‚Äôm in my bed doing my homework and I‚Äôm like, this is me, like, this is who I want to show up as. Other days I am here in Paris wearing Miu Miu, and I‚Äôm like, this is who I want to show up as and this is how I‚Äôm feeling. I don‚Äôt think there‚Äôs ever really one answer to what makes me feel most myself.  
This conversation has been lightly edited and condensed for clarity. 
Rose is a Senior Editor at ELLE overseeing features and projects about women's issues. She is an accomplished and compassionate storyteller and editor who excels in obtaining exclusive interviews and unearthing compelling features.

title: Ariana DeBose Lived Her French Fantasy at Paris Fashion Week
text:
Paris may conjure up images of the Eiffel Tower, people-watching at caf√©s, and no-holds-barred shopping sprees on the Champs-√âlys√©es. For Ariana DeBose, leaning into her French fantasy means waking up early and ‚Äúwandering around a bit aimlessly while listening to √âdith Piaf.‚Äù And that‚Äôs exactly what she did before her pre-show prep for Chanel‚Äôs spring/summer 2024 show at the Grand Palais √âph√©m√®re yesterday.
‚ÄúI love that you can basically walk into any restaurant in Paris and have amazing food,‚Äù she adds. ‚ÄúTruly. It feels like there‚Äôs this incredible standard that comes with French cuisine and yet the environment can feel so casual and full of joie de vivre.‚Äù The same can be said of French style. Case in point: DeBose‚Äôs look, a color story of gold, black, and maroon‚Äîspecifically, a hooded shawl, a going-out top layered under a vest, and pants with metallic detail and an elastic waist (ideal for decadent meals).
‚ÄúChanel really came into my consciousness in 2004 with Baz Luhrmann‚Äôs No.5 the Film featuring Nicole Kidman. I was 13. I had been fascinated by Moulin Rouge, so that collaboration drew me in and began a love affair with the romanticism that exists across the brand.‚Äù Apart from attending the show, largely considered the top billing of Paris Fashion Week, what else is on DeBose‚Äôs bucket list in the capital city? ‚ÄúVisiting the salt marshes of √éle de R√©, going to Gabrielle Chanel‚Äôs apartment on Rue Cambon, and having a martini at Bar Hemingway inside the Ritz. ‚ÄúErnest was a great writer,‚Äù she says. 
Below, DeBose takes ELLE.com along as she gets ready for Chanel‚Äôs spring/summer 2024 show:

title: Ariana Grande and Ethan Slater Are Reportedly Living Together ‚ÄòFull-Time‚Äô in NYC
text:
Ariana Grande and Ethan Slater‚Äôs relationship has become more serious. Nearly one month after Daily Mail first reported that Grande and Slater were living together, a source told Us Weekly that it‚Äôs true. 
‚ÄúEthan informed his friends and soon-to-be ex-wife [Lilly Jay] that he‚Äôs living with Ariana full-time in New York,‚Äù the source said. ‚ÄúThey‚Äôre really happy and really good for each other. All of her friends love him.‚Äù That source didn‚Äôt specify when the private couple moved in.
In Daily Mail‚Äôs initial September 12 report, a source close to the situation claimed: ‚ÄúAriana is living with a married man right now while she is still married [to Dalton Gomez, from whom Grande filed for divorce on September 18]. It seems as if Ariana is holding onto Dalton in case things with Ethan don‚Äôt work. It is just so strange that she is living with Ethan and has not filed documents to end it with Dalton.‚Äù
Gomez filed for divorce immediately after Grande on the 18th. Sources told TMZ that Grande and Gomez worked everything out before they filed, and Grande will ‚Äúcut Dalton a check, and that will be that.‚Äù
Grande and Slater were first seen together in Disney World days later on September 22. They were with family and friends, including Grande‚Äôs mom and brother, and had a private tour guide take them around the Orlando theme park.
Neither Grande nor Slater have commented on their romance or posted about it on their social media. The couple met while working on the movie musical Wicked and were friends before they dated.
Both are currently in the process of divorcing their previous partners, Jay and Gomez. Sources stressed that they did not start seeing each other romantically until after they were separated from their spouses. 
A source additionally told People in early September, ‚ÄúThey are doing their best to balance the fact that they are in the public eye with the desire to be respectful to all parties involved.‚Äù
Jay is the only one of the four to say anything publicly. She told Page Six in late July: ‚Äú[Ariana‚Äôs] the story really. Not a girl‚Äôs girl. My family is just collateral damage.‚Äù

title: Selena Gomez Says She‚Äôs ‚ÄòHappy‚Äô and Now ‚ÄòReally Appreciates the Struggles‚Äô She‚Äôs Had
text:
Every item on this page was chosen by an ELLE editor. We may earn commission on some of the items you choose to buy.
Selena Gomez is doing great, but it was a journey to get there. Gomez spoke to Vogue and People recently about how she feels at 31 after navigating her bipolar diagnosis in 2018, physical and mental health struggles, and of course, fame throughout her childhood, teens, and 20s. 
Gomez has been giving interviews this week following news that on October 10, Sephora will be donating 100 percent of all Rare Beauty sales to her makeup brand‚Äôs Rare Impact Fund, which supports mental heath organizations. 
Gomez told People that she is a fan of her 30s. ‚ÄúI have to say, turning 30 was a good moment for me. I‚Äôm 31 now, and I actually truly feel like the older I‚Äôve gotten, the more I‚Äôve really appreciated the struggles that I‚Äôve had,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúAnd I don‚Äôt necessarily feel like I‚Äôm held back by anything. I just feel like I‚Äôve been honest with the world, I‚Äôve been honest with myself, I‚Äôve called myself out, and I just want to be the best version of myself.‚Äù
It took time for Gomez to get to the good headspace she is in now. ‚ÄúI know it seems easy [to look confident], but I promise you it‚Äôs been years of constant back and forth in my head, and now I‚Äôm just really happy, and I guess it‚Äôs showing, which I‚Äôm really honored.‚Äù
Gomez shared similar comments to Vogue, saying, ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt feel good all the time.‚Äù But spending time with her 10-year-old sister Gracie Elliott does help: ‚ÄúShe reminds me of a perspective in life that can be a bit simpler and pure. Even just having a moment with her makes me feel better.‚Äù
With friends and new people in her life, Gomez is more discerning now too: ‚ÄúI can gauge the difference between someone who wants to actually get to know me versus someone who just wants to know me as a person. I‚Äôm grateful that I can tell.‚Äù
