title: V.E. Schwab Is Rewriting the Rules of Fantasy (And Maybe Life Itself)
text:
Every item on this page was chosen by an ELLE editor. We may earn commission on some of the items you choose to buy.
The author‚Äôs forays into alternate realities aren‚Äôt about escapism. They‚Äôre about power. 
‚ÄúI am somebody who wants the world to be stranger than it is,‚Äù says Victoria ‚ÄúV.E.‚Äù Schwab, her voice dipping toward melancholy as she caps off the sentence. It‚Äôs a curious thought she presents‚Äîconsidering the world is, in fact, consistently and maddeningly bizarre‚Äîand yet one approaching the truth uniting the author‚Äôs works of fantasy, including the bestselling sensation The Invisible Life of Addie LaRue and her latest, the first entry in a new series: The Fragile Threads of Power. 
These stories, which have built Schwab a sizable audience of not only Instagram followers (365K and climbing), but active, engaged readers across platforms and continents, are grounded in what Schwab calls a ‚Äúpoint of departure‚Äù from reality. They are each set in a version of the world we know, but with an asterisk. So: In Addie, there is New York City, and there is Paris, but there is also a god made of shadow who grants wishes that double as curses. In Threads, there is London, but it is carved into multiversal quadrants, versions in various stages of grandeur and ruin: Red London, White London, Grey London, and Black London. There is magic in Schwab‚Äôs work, but it exists along familiar contours, never claiming faraway lands from which to flourish. 
Schwab‚Äôs been, as she puts it, ‚Äúin this game‚Äù since 2009, pumping out books from the age of 19, work that she marks by three essential characteristics: 1) ‚Äúdeeply fleshed-out‚Äù characters; 2) a ‚Äúslow‚Äù initial hundred pages, ‚Äúbecause I‚Äôm laying the board for a game I‚Äôm asking you to play‚Äù; and 3) writing with a ‚Äúvery specific lyrical style.‚Äù She adds, with something of a shrug and a smile, ‚ÄúIf you don‚Äôt like these three things, then my books probably aren‚Äôt for you.‚Äù 
She‚Äôs right, at least in part. Her characters are beloved, if not exactly naturalistic. Her beginnings can grow turgid, though rewarding for the devoted. And her prose is that of a young poet, fond of frequent line breaks and overwrought descriptions but with a slippery, hypnotic cadence. Still, none of these factors are what ultimately make Schwab‚Äôs work so enticing. The appeal is not in the ‚Äústranger‚Äù world that she and her readers desire, but a landscape in which the real world‚Äôs power might become comprehensible‚Äîand therefore, finally, manageable. 
Schwab knew something of bifurcated realities as a child: She grew up between San Jose, California, and Nashville, Tennessee, moving back and forth repeatedly throughout her first 18 years. An only child, she considered herself self-sufficient well before she hit adulthood, and acquired friends as a natural ‚Äúsocial mimic‚Äù who was ‚Äúvery, very intense in everything I did,‚Äù she says. She attended an all-girls preparatory school in Nashville, and she claims she ‚Äúnever‚Äù wanted to be a novelist; she wanted to be a World Cup soccer player. 
But Schwab also enjoyed the expansive isolation of her own mind, where her imagination could nurture a sense of being ‚Äúalone without feeling lonely.‚Äù When she first enrolled in a university, she attended for astrophysics before ‚Äúleapfrogging around different departments‚Äù and signing her first book deal, which might as well have included her signature on the bottom line of life itself: A traditional career path would never be her lot. She‚Äôd been rooting around for this path for years, arguably ever since she picked up reading. 
‚ÄúThe first time I felt transported by a book, my reaction was of two minds,‚Äù she says. ‚ÄúIt wasn‚Äôt even just to be transported. There was a part of my brain at the time that was like, This is power.‚Äù She continues, ‚ÄúI was intoxicated by the idea of the manipulation of words and [what] that could do to somebody else‚Äôs mind far before I ever wrote a novel.‚Äù 
Even as a teenager, Schwab was furious to have these powers of hers taken seriously. I ask if, in the years since she‚Äôs become a traditional publishing success story, she‚Äôs perhaps aged out of that insecurity. She replies, ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think you can age out of it when you start in young-adult, and when you‚Äôre a woman who writes in fantasy.‚Äù 
As a genre, the young-adult label fit her work like a girdle, squeezing it into a specific shape but smoothing the interesting bits along the way. Her first book, 2011‚Äôs The Near Witch, was a fairytale with a teenage protagonist, and ‚Äúat the time, that automatically made it YA,‚Äù Schwab says, adding, ‚ÄúYA can be a beautiful section of the market. But it does feel like it has a lot of rules.‚Äù She was told that her books were unlikely to sell well‚Äîlargely because she didn‚Äôt write within the strict parameters of the romance subgenre‚Äîand that each consecutive YA work would have approximately ‚Äútwo to six months to succeed‚Äù before bookshelves would be cleared for new entries, and hers lost to the ether of unlikely discovery. She continues, ‚ÄúThe most traumatized authors I know are authors who are either in or have come through YA.‚Äù 
When Schwab made the leap to adult fiction with 2013‚Äôs Vicious, she expected a similar timeline for supposed ‚Äúsuccess.‚Äù After two months, she emailed her editor, assuming the deadline had arrived: They‚Äôd now decide if she‚Äôd sold enough copies to cinch herself another book deal. Her editor recommended, instead, that they circle back after two years. ‚ÄúThat was this realization that books got to live longer lives in adult, and find readers at a slower rate,‚Äù Schwab says. ‚ÄúI needed that advantage because Vicious was never a bestseller, but it sold the same number of copies every year for seven or eight years.‚Äù
The publication of Vicious also announced the arrival of her twin literary identities: Victoria Schwab, with which she‚Äôd continue to release books like the Monsters of Verity and Cassidy Blake series, and V.E. Schwab, under which she‚Äôd pen her popular fantasies such as the Shades of Magic trilogy, the Villains books, the newly launched Threads of Power series, and her stand-alone novels including 2020‚Äôs Addie LaRue and 2022‚Äôs Gallant. (Some books would be released under Victoria and later under V.E.) The pseudonym was both a marketing tool and a self-protective measure: Such a gender-neutral name allowed her‚Äîin theory, anyway‚Äîto reach new audiences, as well as to create ‚Äúa version of me that lives rent-free in people‚Äôs heads,‚Äù she explains. To her friends and family, she‚Äôs Victoria. But online, and to her many followers, she‚Äôs V.E., maker of tangential realities, not ‚Äúthe human who wakes up at 7 a.m. and walks my dog on the beach.‚Äù In other words, V.E. could have power, while Victoria could live. 
During the height of the pandemic, Addie LaRue took off‚Äîa miracle Schwab attributes, not entirely in jest, to its ‚Äúvery sexy villain.‚Äù But she recognizes the book was also ‚Äúinextricable from the time in which it was published.‚Äù After its initial release in October 2020, Addie hit the New York Times bestseller list, but it was only after popular book-centric creators on TikTok (a.k.a. BookTok) championed the novel that it became a true phenomenon. Addie‚Äîabout a twenty-something girl cursed to be forgotten by everyone she meets throughout multiple centuries, but who falls in love nevertheless‚Äîwas the kind of book readers wanted, and perhaps needed, during COVID: ‚Äúdefiantly hopeful,‚Äù as Schwab puts it, and a tale of endurance across borders and eras and unbeatable odds. 
Unprompted, Schwab suggests that this, actually, is the real unifying theme across her books: the so-called ‚Äúmastery‚Äù of death. She explains that, as a child, she fretted over her father, a type-one diabetic whose blood sugar levels she helped to monitor, and whose tenuous health created an environment where constant observation was paramount to survival. She concludes, ‚ÄúI just became convinced, if I pay enough attention to everything happening around me, I can control everything. And if you think about what writing novels is, it‚Äôs exercising control.‚Äù
She admits, but does not apologize for, how this rationale might come across. It‚Äôs ‚Äúmanipulation,‚Äù she says, and ‚Äúwanting to have some power over a reader‚Äôs mind,‚Äù even if ‚Äúit sounds narcissistic to put it that way.‚Äù Of course, creating fictional realities is an act of narcissism, perhaps one of the few narcissistic acts that might also serve a benevolent purpose. But this doesn‚Äôt upset Schwab. On the contrary, it thrills her. She talks of feeling powerless as a child, and how she searched rock faces in California hoping to find key holes, anything that might confirm her doubts that reality wasn‚Äôt‚Äîor shouldn‚Äôt be‚Äîwhat it seemed. When she came out as gay in her late twenties, it was further confirmation to herself that reality had always been different than what she‚Äôd initially perceived. Doors were opening. Light was coming through. As she chronicled in a coming-out essay for Oprah Daily in 2020, she exited a metaphorical ‚Äúhouse,‚Äù and the world around her became suddenly stranger, and all the more beautiful. 
But Schwab‚Äîand the world itself‚Äîdid not actually become stranger; it was the perception of Schwab herself that expanded. 
‚ÄúGood fantasy is only escapism for people who already have everything that they need and want in reality,‚Äù Schwab says. In other words: What the author, and her audience, really yearn for is the power‚Äîthe tools of ‚Äúmanipulation,‚Äù as it were‚Äîto rewrite the stubborn, heartbreaking rules that govern our real world. It‚Äôs not that reality isn‚Äôt sufficiently strange; it‚Äôs that it‚Äôs so very hard to control.
Schwab is currently on book tour for The Fragile Threads of Power, a nearly six-week trip spanning multiple cities across the U.S., Ireland, and the U.K. It‚Äôs a grueling schedule, especially as she‚Äôs much more accustomed to a regular writing routine from her favorite coffee shop in Edinburgh, Scotland, where she lives when she‚Äôs not traveling. ‚ÄúI like living in old places, in places that haven‚Äôt felt the need to choose between the realistic and the supernatural,‚Äù she says, citing her neighbors‚Äô affection for ghost stories. ‚ÄúI feel like growing up in the States, by virtue of how young a country it is‚Ä¶it feels so resistant to the supernatural. You either have to be a believer or a non-believer.‚Äù 
This split down the middle is a familiar source of both the author‚Äôs ire and inspiration. There‚Äôs always a separation‚ÄîVictoria and V.E., reality and imagination, the strange and mundane‚Äîthat Schwab wants to smother, or otherwise pull taut between her fingers like twine. And it extends to her publishing career, where she‚Äôs often felt shoved into disparate categories, whether on account of her success (or lack thereof); her gender; her sexuality; or her genre of choice. She wants the freedom just to be, to play, to write and be accepted for it without caveat, much in the manner of her literary icons: Imagine, if you will, Neil Gaiman or Stephen King ever needing introduce themselves as ‚Äúbest-selling male fantasy authors.‚Äù
‚ÄúIt feels like I‚Äôm stuck with this choice,‚Äù she says. ‚ÄúI either downplay pieces of my identity: I take a gender-neutral pseudonym as I did. I try to be mainstream. I try to be palatable, and I still get disqualified. So then I try to be proud, and I try to be loud, and I try to be aggressively femme and gay, and I still get disqualified, where I still get put in a subcategory. And I just want to be like, How big do you have to get as a fantasy author before you don‚Äôt have to be caveated as something smaller?‚Äù
In the midst of this specific struggle, Schwab also has to contend with the demands of a shifting industry: Readers have come to expect a relationship with her over social media, whether in the form of her Instagram or her newsletter, featuring the cheeky title ‚ÄúThe Visible Life of V.E. Schwab.‚Äù And she recognizes that even these engaged followers don‚Äôt necessarily belong to the same category. Some are Addie fans; others come for Shades of Magic; still others clamor for the third and final entry in her Villains series. Because she hops between books and series and settings, her audience is not a ‚Äúhomogenous‚Äù one. ‚ÄúSometimes I get very panicky,‚Äù she admits, ‚Äúbecause I think I can‚Äôt appease them all because I only write one book at a time.‚Äù
And she feels, yes, ‚Äúan immense pressure to perform author-hood,‚Äù she says. ‚ÄúI always am like, the person I‚Äôm most jealous of in this entire world is Donna Tartt. Talk about a person who‚Äôs just, ‚ÄòTake the myth of me and run! You‚Äôll never see me.‚Äô I‚Äôll say to my friends, like, ‚ÄòWhat a dream. What a dream to just be a mythological figure.‚Äô‚Äù
Of course, she seems to amend this notion the next time we speak: ‚ÄúThe insanity-inducing thing is that I insist on being online. If I could not engage‚Äîbut, to me, engagement is part of what I love.‚Äù It‚Äôs also part of the Sisyphean task of building a readership in an era where attention is a fickle currency. ‚ÄúThe conversation I have with [my publicist] every week is like, Am I going to be relevant?‚Äù 
Schwab yearns to have an end goal in sight, both in the context of her life and in her fiction. She outlines every book with a specific ending in mind; she never begins a project without having already decided on its finale. But getting to that ending‚Äîthat‚Äôs where she gets to experiment. For these periods, she can play in the ‚Äòwhat if‚Äô she recalls from a memory ironed in her teenage brain, when she went walking along a wooden fence and stumbled upon a door just beyond it. I‚Äôll let the author tell it:
‚ÄúThere was a door standing upright in this empty yard, as if the rest of the house had been razed around it, but this door has not been razed. And I remember reaching the end of this fence and standing there and staring at this door. My mind was like, What if I open that door, and it‚Äôs not the yard on the other side? But that same ‚Äòwhat if‚Äô is what prevented me from opening the door. Because as long as I didn‚Äôt open the door, as long as I only lived in the ‚Äòwhat if,‚Äô there was a potential that I would open the door and see somewhere else. The moment I opened the door and didn‚Äôt see somewhere else, it would suck. It would be a return to the norm. ‚Äù Ending this anecdote, she summarizes, ‚ÄúAnd reading is living in the potential of what could be, and not in the confirmation of what is.‚Äù
This statement, like Schwab‚Äôs desire for a ‚Äústranger‚Äù world, is not an entirely accurate one. Reading‚Äîeven, or perhaps especially, in the fantasy genre‚Äîconfirms exactly ‚Äúwhat is‚Äù: that the world is strange; that it is inhabited by dark and terrible forces; that behind every door there is the opportunity for change. But sometimes the best way of navigating such an utterly confounding reality is not by approaching it unarmed. As Addie, and Vicious, and Threads all prove, sometimes it takes magic to see the monsters clearly‚Äîand to finally beat them back.

title: Laphonza Butler Will Become the First Black Lesbian to Serve in Congress
text:
Gov. Gavin Newsom tapped the EMILY‚Äôs List president to fill Dianne Feinstein‚Äôs Senate seat.
Laphonza Butler, president of the political action committee EMILY‚Äôs List, will be Congress‚Äôs first-ever Black lesbian senator.
California Gov. Gavin Newsom tapped Butler to fill the Senate seat that was left empty after the death of Dianne Feinstein,  Politico reported. Her appointment marks a historic first for Congress, with Butler becoming the sole Black woman currently serving and the third-ever Black woman to ever serve in the Senate. She will also be the first openly LGBTQ+ Black woman to work in Congress.
‚ÄúI‚Äôm honored to accept Gov. @GavinNewsom‚Äôs nomination to be U.S. Senator for a state I have made my home and honored by his trust in me to serve the people of California and this great nation,‚Äù Butler said in a statement posted on X, formerly known as Twitter. ‚ÄúNo one will ever measure up to the legacy of Sen. Dianne Feinstein, but I will do my best to honor her legacy and leadership by committing to work for women and girls, workers and unions, struggling parents, and all of California. I am ready to serve.‚Äù
Butler has served as president of EMILY‚Äôs List, an organization that works to elect pro-choice Democratic women, since 2021.
She previously worked as the director of public policy and campaigns in North America for Airbnb, a strategist and partner at political consulting firm SCRB Strategies, and a senior advisor for Vice President Kamala Harris‚Äôs 2020 presidential campaign. She also has a long and involved history with the labor movement, having served as the president of home-care workers union SEIU Local 2015 for more than a decade. 
Other high-profile California Democrats are currently running for Feinstein‚Äôs seat‚Äîshe was the longest-serving female senator in U.S. history prior to her passing at 90 years old‚Äîwhich will be up for grabs in the 2024 midterms. These include Reps. Adam Schiff, Katie Porter, and Barbara Lee.
CNN reports that Newsom had previously promised to appoint a Black woman if Feinstein, who announced earlier this year that she would not run for reelection, were to resign from her seat earlier than planned. Many had hoped the governor would select Lee, the former chair of the Congressional Black Caucus, as Feinstein‚Äôs replacement. However, Newsom opted to not choose any of the candidates participating in the 2024 Senate election, so as not to give any particular candidate an advantage over others ahead of time. Though Butler herself may choose to run for office next year, too.
‚ÄúAs we mourn the enormous loss of Sen. Feinstein, the very freedoms she fought for‚Äîreproductive freedom, equal protection, and safety from gun violence‚Äîhave never been under greater assault,‚Äù Newsom said in a statement on X. ‚ÄúLaphonza has spent her entire career fighting for women and girls and has been a fierce advocate for working people.‚Äù
He concluded, ‚ÄúI have no doubt she will carry the baton left by Senator Feinstein, continue to break glass ceilings, and fight for all Californians in Washington.‚Äù
As an associate editor at HarpersBAZAAR.com, Chelsey keeps a finger on the pulse on all things celeb news. She also writes on social movements, connecting with activists leading the fight on workers' rights, climate justice, and more. Offline, she‚Äôs probably spending too much time on TikTok, rewatching Emma (the 2020 version, of course), or buying yet another corset.¬†

title: Gigi Hadid Struts the Miu Miu Runway With Hangover Hair
text:
Relatable. 
Do you remember your hair at the end of finals week in high school? Or the hair that your favorite bodega person sees on a weekly basis? Or perhaps it was just last week when you ventured outside to grab a bagel during NYC‚Äôs hurricane? 
Somewhere, somehow, Miu Miu saw your hair, put it on the inspiration board and added it to the runway for their Spring Summer 2024 show.
After a full Fashion Month of very glamorous hair including the big hair bouffants at Schiaparelli, the sleek French twists at Dior, and pretty beach waves at Chanel, Miu Miu gave us greasy, oily, hangover hair and honestly, it was nice to feel seen. ‚ÄúIt was greasy, stringy hair, I loved it,‚Äù a friend texted me after the show. From runway photos, the hair looked oily (not shiny), matted (not artfully tousled), clumpy (not as cute as Taylor Swift‚Äôs wet hair during the Eras tour), like the hairstylists played a game of ‚Äúhide the dry shampoo‚Äù backstage.
The amount of dishevelment varied. From the neck up, Gigi Hadid looked like she was walking home after cramming for an all nighter at the library, paired with sequin board shorts and thick glasses. Model Rianne Van Rompaey‚Äôs hair was so lank and ropey, drawn into a low pony, that it reminded me of my hair at the end of any hike where I‚Äôve ever gotten lost. It‚Äôs a slight departure from the staticky cloud hair of last season, in which the models looked like their heads were rubbed with helium balloons (and it turns out they were, to get the effect.) I probably don‚Äôt need to know how to get the Miu Miu hair look, but I‚Äôd love to know about the inspiration.

She was also a co-founder of Donate Beauty, a grassroots beauty donation project started during the COVID-19 crisis, which donated over 500,000 products to over 30,000 healthcare workers across 500+ hospitals.¬†

title: Where Is Mike Jeffries, Abercrombie & Fitch‚Äôs Former CEO, Now?
text:
Netflix‚Äôs documentary White Hot: The Rise & Fall of Abercrombie & Fitch charts the messy trajectory of the once-cooler-than-cool mall store that peaked in the ‚Äò90s and early 2000s, only to come crashing down after a string of racist, exclusionary controversies. The man at the center of the brand‚Äôs peaks and valleys? Mike Jeffries, A&F‚Äôs former CEO, who‚Äôs described by the documentary‚Äôs subjects as ‚Äúprivate,‚Äù a ‚Äúmicromanager,‚Äù a creative ‚Äúmad genius,‚Äù and simply ‚Äúbizarre.‚Äù
Leslie Wexner first brought California-born Jeffries onto A&F in 1992, hoping he could revamp the 100-year-old brand. At the time, Jeffries was known as the former president of Alcott & Andrews, a women‚Äôs retail chain that filed for bankruptcy in 1989. Wexner, on the other hand, was the king of retail; he was the CEO of A&F‚Äôs then-parent company L Brands, which owned stores like The Limited and Victoria‚Äôs Secret. The documentary describes how it was Jeffries‚Äô strategy to center this new iteration of A&F around elitism, sex, and exclusivity. According to the doc, Jeffries had rigid perceptions of masculinity and femininity, which he infused into A&F‚Äôs image.
Jeffries also brought on famed photographer Bruce Weber, who‚Äôs credited with helping to establish the aesthetic of the company's golden age. (All those A&F shopping bags with black-and-white photos of half-naked men? Part of Weber‚Äôs vision.) In recent years, more than 20 current and former models have come forward to accuse Weber of sexual assault and exploitation. He has since settled two sexual assault lawsuits and has not admitted guilt. Wexner has also come under scrutiny for his close ties to the late Jeffrey Epstein, the convicted sex offender who was found dead while awaiting trial on sex trafficking charges. Wexner retired as CEO of L Brands in 2020 and left the board in March 2021.
At first, under Jeffries, A&F saw incredible success, and in 1996, he took the company public. But he was also the leader as A&F confronted scandal after scandal. In 2002, there were protests over racist T-shirts and suggestive thongs marketed to pre-teen girls.  A group of ex-employees sued A&F in a class-action lawsuit in 2003 for racial discrimination. (A&F settled for $40 million and admitted no wrongdoing.) And then there was the rare interview Jeffries gave to Salon in 2006. In the story, Jeffries is described as a ‚Äúquirky perfectionist and control freak,‚Äù who always goes through the revolving doors at A&F headquarters twice and never passes other employees on the stairwells. During the interview, he infamously said: ‚ÄúCandidly, we go after the cool kids. We go after the attractive all-American kid with a great attitude and a lot of friends. A lot of people don‚Äôt belong [in our clothes], and they can‚Äôt belong. Are we exclusionary? Absolutely.‚Äù
From there, the controversies only continued to mount. In 2012, Bloomberg reported on an ‚ÄúAircraft Standards‚Äù manual for the A&F executive jet, written by Jeffries‚Äôs longtime life partner Matthew Smith. (The manual was made public in an age-discrimination lawsuit brought against the company by a former pilot, according to Bloomberg.) The manual included 40 pages of highly detailed instructions, including what kind of underwear aircraft staff should wear and the seating arrangements for Jeffries‚Äôs dogs.  Then in 2013, BuzzFeed News published reporting that Smith was ‚Äúone of the most powerful people‚Äù at A&F, even though he wasn‚Äôt technically employed and his role was ‚Äúnever formally reported‚Äù to shareholders. Per the report, ‚ÄúTwo former executives used the word ‚Äòdangerous‚Äô when describing Smith, citing the fact that he is organizationally unaccountable if something were to go wrong with regard to a decision he‚Äôs made.‚Äù
After reports of struggling sales, Jeffries finally stepped down from A&F in December 2014, nearly a year after he was removed as chairman. In June 2015, Samantha Elauf won a Supreme Court case against A&F after the company refused to hire her because she wore a headscarf.
Once he departed A&F, Jeffries mostly stayed out of the news. Some of the biggest updates were that in 2015, the company sold the corporate jet, and in 2016, Jeffries listed his Manhattan townhouse for $19.5 million. He then relisted it a year later for $16 million, per ELLE Decor, and it ended up selling in 2018 for $12.9 million.
But in 2023, he was back in headlines again after a BBC investigation found that a group of men alleged Jeffries and Smith exploited them for sex during events they hosted around the world. The outlet stated: ‚ÄúTwo former US prosecutors who independently reviewed documents and testimony uncovered by the BBC have called for an investigation to determine whether charges for sex trafficking could be brought.‚Äù
One of the men told the BBC that Jeffries was the ‚Äúkingpin‚Äù and that he ‚Äútook advantage of people in a very vulnerable point in their life, especially when they‚Äôre around these big cities, coming from small America.‚Äù
While neither Jeffries nor Smith have commented on the accusations, A&F told the BBC it‚Äôs ‚Äúappalled and disgusted‚Äù by the alleged behavior and that new leadership has changed the company into the ‚Äúvalues-driven organization we are today‚Äù with ‚Äúzero tolerance for abuse, harassment or discrimination of any kind.‚Äù
Fran Horowitz is A&F‚Äôs current CEO, and under her, the brand has transformed, this time focusing on diversity, size inclusivity, and a more understated, trendier clothing selection. But much like the A&F cologne that smacks you in the face on your way into the store, Jeffries‚Äôs influence on the brand will always linger. 
Watch White Hot: The Rise & Fall of Abercrombie & Fitch on Netflix now.

title: Selena Gomez on What Happened When She Unfollowed Dua Lipa: ‚ÄòIt Was an Accident‚Äô
text:
Selena Gomez caused a bit of drama online in June when she suddenly unfollowed Zayn Malik, who she had been rumored to be dating in the spring, his ex-girlfriend Gigi Hadid, her sister Bella Hadid, Zendaya, and Dua Lipa on Instagram.
In her new interview with Fast Company, Gomez revealed that unfollowing Lipa really was not on purpose. (In fact, Gomez re-followed Lipa and Zendaya. Today, she still follows them.)
Regarding Lipa specifically, ‚ÄúIt was an accident!‚Äù Gomez said with a laugh. ‚ÄúI was just cleaning up some of my Instagram. Then somebody called me and was like, ‚ÄòWhat happened with Dua?!‚Äô‚Äù
Nothing, and Gomez went above and beyond to make that publicly clear.
Gomez even wore a dress from Versace and Dua Lipa‚Äôs collaboration to a Rare Beauty event.
Gomez posted the Versace look on Instagram, captioning her image, ‚ÄúA little Versace/Dua moment ü¶ã‚Äù. Lipa commented, ‚Äúangeeeeeeeel!!!! üòçüòçüòçüòç‚Äù in further proof that all was well.
Gomez also spoke about her upcoming album in Fast Company‚Äôs wide-ranging interview, in addition to how heartbreak influenced her decision to quit Instagram in 2018. 
With her new music specifically, happy songs are coming, she said. ‚ÄúI love sad-girl music; I‚Äôm really good at that,‚Äù she admitted. ‚ÄúHowever, I can‚Äôt really write that if I‚Äôm not sad. I‚Äôve had to relearn what being me and being happy looked like. There is not one sad song on this whole album.‚Äù
Still, ‚ÄúI‚Äôve never promised anyone that I‚Äôll never have a bad day again,‚Äù she stressed. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve always been honest with my fans. Even when I take breaks from social media, I‚Äôll say I‚Äôm taking a break.
Alyssa Bailey is the senior news and strategy editor at ELLE.com, where she oversees coverage of celebrities and royals (particularly Meghan Markle and Kate Middleton). title: Priscilla: Everything to Know About Sofia Coppola‚Äôs Priscilla Presley Film
text:
Every item on this page was chosen by an ELLE editor. We may earn commission on some of the items you choose to buy.
Last year, Baz Lurhmann‚Äôs Elvis biopic was everywhere from the Met Gala to awards season. This year, it‚Äôs Priscilla Presley‚Äôs time to shine.
Sofia Coppola is writing, directing, and producing the film Priscilla, adapted from Priscilla Beaulieu Presley‚Äôs 1985 memoir, Elvis and Me. Cailee Spaeny, best known for roles in Mare of Easttown, Bad Times at El Royale, and On the Basis of Sex, will star in the titular role. Meanwhile Euphoria‚Äôs Jacob Elordi will star opposite her as the King of Rock n Roll.
Here‚Äôs what else we know so far. 
Here‚Äôs the official synopsis from A24: 
‚ÄúHer story was so vivid in my mind and the visuals of that world, Memphis, the ‚Äô60s. It‚Äôs so American,‚Äù Coppola told The Hollywood Reporter. ‚ÄúAnd I always like themes about finding one‚Äôs identity and teenage girls growing into adulthood.‚Äù 
The filmmaker also connected to Presley‚Äôs story as someone who also came of age in the orbit of a towering cultural figure: her father, Francis Ford Coppola. ‚ÄúI know from my family what it‚Äôs like to be inside a show business family,‚Äù she added to THR.
Given its unflinching portrayal of Priscilla‚Äôs life, the film shows a side of Elvis that may be hard to watch for fans. These include his courting Priscilla when she was 14 and he was 24, choosing her clothes for her to wear, and giving her a black eye during a pillow fight, per THR. ‚ÄúIt was a different time,‚Äù Priscilla Presley told Hollywood Reporter. ‚ÄúI lived in his world. I wanted to please him. I wanted to fit in. I wanted to have fun with him. I‚ÄØwanted to see what it was that he liked.‚Äù
Aside from Spaeny and Elordi, Succession's Dagmara Domi≈Ñczyk plays Priscilla‚Äôs mother. 
Though Coppola considered a number of actors for the role of Elvis, Spaeny was always her first choice for Priscilla, Deadline reports. When she finally met with Elordi for coffee in New York, ‚Äúall the girls in the room just turned to him, they gravitated,‚Äù she told THR. ‚ÄúI just felt like, ‚ÄòYeah, he has that kind of charisma that I imagine Elvis had.‚Äô‚Äù
The team behind the scenes includes: cinematographer Philippe Le Sourd, costume designer Stacey Battat, editor Sarah Flack, and production designer Tamara Deverell‚Äîall longtime Coppola collaborators, according to Variety. 
Priscilla arrives in theaters on November 3, 2023 via A24. It just premiered at Venice Film Festival in early September. Production began last fall in Toronto. 
Catch the teaser above and watch the official trailer below. 
‚ÄúThe people who are watching, they‚Äôre living it with you, and you hope and pray that they get it. They get your feelings, your hurts, your sensitivity,‚Äù the film's subject told THR. 
At the premiere in Venice this month, Presley appeared to be moved and was seen wiping away tears at the end of the screening. She praised the film at a press conference after, saying ‚ÄúSofia did an amazing job,‚Äù per Vulture. 
She also took a moment to address some of the movie‚Äôs controversial moments, such as her age gap with Elvis and their sexual dynamic. 
‚ÄúI was more of a listener,‚Äù she said, according to Vulture. ‚ÄúElvis would pour his heart out to me in every way in Germany: his fears, his hopes, the loss of his mother, which he never, ever got over. I was the person who really, really sat there to listen and to comfort him. That was really our connection, even though I was 14 ‚Ä¶ I was older in life than in numbers.‚Äù
She added, ‚ÄúPeople think that was the attraction ‚Äî it was sex. Not at all. I never had sex with him. He was very kind, very soft, very loving, but he also respected the fact I was only 14 years old. We were more in mind and thought, and that was our relationship ‚Ä¶ We built a relationship, and that relationship went on until, yes, I left, and it wasn‚Äôt because I didn‚Äôt love him. He was the love of my life. It was the lifestyle that was so difficult for me, and I think any woman can relate to that, but it didn‚Äôt mar our relationship. We still remained very close, and of course, we had our daughter, and I made sure that he saw her all the time. It was like we never left each other, so I want to make that clear.‚Äù
The estate is reportedly unhappy with Priscilla. TMZ reported in June that it was made without the estate's knowledge or consent. One official even told the outlet the film was ‚Äúhorrible.‚Äù 
In response to the criticism, Prisicilla Presley told TMZ, ‚ÄúI am very excited to see the interpretation of my book by the masterful Sofia Coppola. She has such an extraordinary perspective and I have always been such an admirer of her work. I'm certain this movie will take everyone on an emotional journey.‚Äù
Elvis Presley Enterprises also turned down requests to include Presley's own music in the film. ‚ÄúThey don‚Äôt like projects that they haven‚Äôt originated, and they‚Äôre protective of their brand,‚Äù Coppola told THR. ‚ÄúBut that made us be more creative.‚Äù

title: Selena Gomez on Why Her Final Justin Bieber Breakup Led Her to Dump Instagram Too
text:
Selena Gomez was the most followed woman on Instagram when she deleted the app and gave control of her account to an assistant in 2018. In a new interview with Fast Company, Gomez explained that her final breakup with Justin Bieber in spring 2018, after their 8-year on-off romance, led her to dump Instagram too. 
Bieber, of course, started dating his now-wife Hailey Bieber just months after, in June 2018. They got engaged a month later, and then married in September 2018. 
Gomez recalled her headspace at the time: ‚ÄúI had just gotten my heart broken. I didn‚Äôt need to see what everyone was doing,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúThen there were those moments of not feeling positive about how I looked because of what I‚Äôd see on Instagram. Wow, I wish my body looked like that.‚Äù 
She explained having her own body change also impacted how she viewed herself. Before, she‚Äôd ‚Äúhad a teenager‚Äôs body,‚Äù she said. And now, ‚Äúnone of the sample sizes were fitting, and that would make me feel embarrassed. Although how unrealistic is it to expect a normal woman‚Äôs body not to change?‚Äù
At the same time, Gomez was navigating her own mental health. In 2018, she was diagnosed with bipolar disorder. Two years later, she shared her diagnosis publicly on Miley Cyrus‚Äô Bright Minded Instagram Live show.
Initially, Gomez worried about the consequences of sharing her mental health struggles and condition. ‚ÄúI grew up being a people pleaser,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúI had a responsibility at a very young age‚Äîyoung people were looking up to me. I didn‚Äôt know who I was. Having that responsibility would make me walk on eggshells a lot. I thought maybe it would be damaging to tell people who I am. It started to become a threat that freaked me out. Well, if you‚Äôre not right, then you can‚Äôt work.‚Äù
She reflected on the time just before she was diagnosed: ‚ÄúI went through a really hard season [then]. It was my highs and my lows, and I didn‚Äôt know what to do, so I couldn‚Äôt control it. I would want to cancel things. It was just a tormented feeling. That‚Äôs why, when I found out my diagnosis, it was just, ‚ÄòOh, okay, I feel a bit relieved, I understand a bit more.‚Äô I got second opinions. I went to doctors. I‚Äôm fortunate enough to be able to have people who can help me survive every day.‚Äù  
As a celebrity now, Gomez puts herself in a different category than stars like Beyonc√© and Adele. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not unattainable,‚Äù she said of herself generally. ‚ÄúI look at someone like a Beyonc√©, and I am amazed. My jaw drops. Every part of her is just impeccable, and it‚Äôs just so beautiful. I went to her show and was blown away. But I‚Äôm just not that, and that‚Äôs okay. I‚Äôm me, and I‚Äôm a little silly, but I also like being sexy and fun, and I also want to do good with the time I have here. We need goddesses like Beyonc√© and Adele. But I‚Äôm just happy to be your best friend.‚Äù

title: 13 At-Home Laser Hair Removal Devices That Actually Work
text:
Every item on this page was chosen by an ELLE editor. We may earn commission on some of the items you choose to buy.
Flawless skin with just one zap.
While you might be feeling down about the end of summer, the fall and winter seasons are the perfect time to finally test out some of the best at-home laser hair removal tools. Even though the convenience of using your favorite razor in the shower is an excellent option for hair removal, it can be tedious, result in ingrown hairs, and become an exhausting process if what you‚Äôre after is skin as smooth as a baby seal. If you‚Äôre anything like me, using an at-home hair removal device is equally thrilling and terrifying. I find shaving tedious, but my first foray into permanent hair removal didn‚Äôt go well. After spending hundreds of dollars at an esthetician‚Äôs office, I found laser hair removal was not effective enough to justify the pain. Because I‚Äôm someone who can easily cosplay as Snow White (pale skin, dark hair, high tolerance for short men), I‚Äôm the ideal candidate for laser hair removal. But alas, I had to give it up for the sake of my sanity and my wallet.
I thought I was resigned to using a razor forever. Then, I stumbled upon the Braun IPL Silk Expert Pro device. Not only was it significantly cheaper, less painful, and less humiliating than the salon service, but I actually started to see results quickly. For all of the many methods of body-hair removal out there‚Äîfrom shaving with the best razors to sugaring to waxing‚Äîlaser hair removal (both professional and at home) is the only strategy that promises more permanent results. 
At-home handheld hair removal devices come in two categories: IPL or a diode laser. Most at-home laser hair removal devices rely on IPL‚Äîintense pulsated light‚Äîtherapy, in which tiny beams of light at different wavelengths zap the bulb within each hair follicle. ‚ÄúIn essence, it is using heat to destroy the hair follicles,‚Äù says dermatologist Dr. Marisa K. Garshick, who mentions that dermatologists also use versions of IPL for photo rejuvenation procedures (a.k.a. fading dark spots). On the flip side, diode laser technology uses one single wavelength of light, which experts say can help minimize damage to the surrounding skin and be used safely on all skin types and shades. The light is selectively absorbed by the pigment, or melanin, within the hair follicle, making it a more targeted (and often more effective) approach to hair removal. 
According to dermatologist Dr. Karan Lal, it‚Äôs important to note that most at-home devices are ‚Äúbest suited for small to medium hairs in small areas‚Äîupper lip, chin, cheeks, bikini, etc.,‚Äù he says. ‚ÄúThey are typically not meant for large surface areas like the back.‚Äù (There are a few exceptions, but we‚Äôll get to that later).
To help you wade through the treacherous waters of the World Wide Web, we consulted our experts and customer reviews to find the 13 best at-home laser hair removal devices for women.

If your pain tolerance is somewhat low, you may want to reach for this device with cooling technology that reduces laser heat and inflammation. What‚Äôs more, it has three other attachments and is rechargeable.

It‚Äôs no secret that laser hair removal can be uncomfortable at times. Here's an option that is borderline pain-free. The laser on this machine feels more like an ice cube to the skin, which helps minimize pain and soothe the skin. It‚Äôs got two modes for large and small areas and five energy levels to adapt to different hair densities and skin sensitivities.

Unlike many at-home IPL devices, this one is suitable for several skin types and hair colors, and, according to reviewers, it‚Äôs also a gentler option than many others on the market. The device itself isn‚Äôt rechargeable or corded; it comes pre-charged with 400,000 light pulses, which the company claims will last a ‚Äúlifetime.‚Äù

Hair color: Black to blonde hair

What people are saying: ‚ÄúThis product does work! It may not work as well as the professional treatments, but with patience, the cost benefit and easy access make treating yourself at home well worth it.‚Äù
Dr. Marisa K. Garshick is a dermatologist practicing with MCDS Dermatology in New York and New Jersey.
Dr. Karan Lal is a dermatologist and director of pediatric dermatology and cosmetic surgery at Affiliated Dermatology in Scottsdale, Arizona. 
‚ÄúBoth IPL and diode devices rely on the same target, which is the pigment of the hair follicle, to have an effect,‚Äù Dr. Garshick says. She adds, ‚ÄúAt the most basic level, the diode refers to an actual laser, while the IPL is a light-based device.‚ÄùWith a bit of consistency and a lot of patience whichever light beam route you opt for will come with real results. Typically, it will take at least a few sessions to see any change, and each session should be spaced out at least one week apart. Remember always to follow the instructions of your specific device.
Depending on the intensity level of the laser (many of the devices have multiple settings), it can feel uncomfortable. When each follicle gets zapped, it might sting a bit‚Äîmany people compare it to a rubber band being snapped on the skin. But hey, no pain, no gain, right?
Before you start shopping (and zapping) away, we do have one important editor‚Äôs note: Since laser hair removal relies on melanin to produce results, it‚Äôs often not effective on lighter hair colors, like blonde and light gray, which, by nature, contain less pigment. If you have a lighter hair color, consult with a dermatologist before investing your money into an expensive at-home device. Also, read the fine print of every product description because most companies disclose this information upfront. Laser hair removal is also safe for people of color, but certain lasers can cause hyperpigmentation and irritation on darker skin tones, so again, it is best to consult your dermatologist.
Generally speaking, laser hair removal devices are safe. But that doesn‚Äôt mean you shouldn‚Äôt take proper precautions. ‚ÄúAt-home laser hair removal can be safe,‚Äù says Dr. Lal. However,  he adds, ‚ÄúIt is not universally safe because many factors play a role in safety. All available devices are safe for those with light skin and dark hair.‚Äù Needless to say, burns and redness can still occur with less powerful at-home devices. Contact a doctor if you are concerned or notice any discomfort or irritation. 
Dr. Lal has a few helpful tips to make removal easier and safer: ‚ÄúBe sure to have tiny stubble the laser can pick up for treatment. Make sure the device you are using is suitable for your skin color and hair color. Don‚Äôt use this laser if you have red or very light blonde hair. Don‚Äôt over-pulse the laser in the same location as this could lead to burns.‚Äù
For in-office treatments, ‚ÄúThe gold standard is the Gentlemax Pro by Candela. It is a dual alexandrite and Nd-Yag laser that can treat all skin types, hairs of various sizes, and in various locations,‚Äù says Dr. Lal.

title: 12 Ballet Flats With Real Arch Support, According to an Expert Who‚Äôs ‚ÄòEn Pointe‚Äô
text:
Every item on this page was chosen by an ELLE editor. We may earn commission on some of the items you choose to buy.
Wear this season‚Äôs most popular styles in complete comfort.
All of my prima ballerinas out there know too well that those pink satin dancing shoes fall far from the realm of comfort. Consequentially, their watered-down, functional fashion counterpart, the ballet flat, doesn‚Äôt exactly provide much in the way of relief or reinforcement, either. So while the concept of ballet flats with arch support may seem contradictory, rest assured that you can still wear one of this season‚Äôs hottest fall shoe trends without totally compromising comfort.
And who better to pirouette-turn to than Dr. Ann Anderson, podiatrist and podiatric surgeon with a background in ballet? ‚ÄúA ballet flat will not usually give as much arch support as a sneaker,‚Äù she admits. ‚ÄúBut [they] can be supportive if the construction of the shoe incorporates an arch support...‚Äù Despite the name, a ‚Äúflat‚Äù shoe can still offer adequate support if it‚Äôs intentionally designed. 
Thankfully, certain brands have mastered the art of comfortable ballet flats. Anderson suggests looking for a heel cup or arch support that is part of the shoe design in order to help support your foot overall. Below, shop the 12 best ballet flats with arch support to wear this season.
In all likelihood, you‚Äôve already seen Vivaia flats trending across social media, touting extreme comfort and earth-friendly composition. Complete with an Armisia Argy herbal insole, the Aria 5¬∞  provides promising heel rebound, arch and forefront support, and a padded  heel patch for extra cushy comfort. I think we can all agree, 6 plastic bottles never looked this good...the first thing I noticed was the insole; these are now more cushioned and structured around the arches and toes.‚Äù
A style I‚Äôm most looking forward to wearing this season, the Mary Jane makes a case for comfort with this square-toed, patent pair of flats from Cole Haan. An easy accomplice for fall denim or cozy sweater dresses, this shoe is lightweight and comes equipped with additional arch support.

If you only add one shoe to your closet this year, make it a ruby red slipper. A lovechild of the classic ballet flat and timeless loafer, this airy flat comes with a molded EVA insole and a memory foam midsole. It‚Äôs also available in multiple widths, so it‚Äôs great for those with particularly wide or narrow feet.

Sizes: 5-11

Customer review: ‚ÄúLOVE the jade green color!‚Äù
If you‚Äôre looking to add a little bedazzle and pizzazz to your everyday black-on-black ensemble, these flats from Birdies proudly display a subtle jacquard pattern and bejeweled strap, alongside seven layers of ‚Äúcloud-like comfort‚Äù in the footbed.

Customer review: ‚ÄúSuper cute and comfortable flats! Felt a little snug at first, but fit well after wearing around the house for a little bit. Perfect addition to my workwear wardrobe!‚Äù
Anderson lists Vionic as one of her favorite brands when it comes to comfort and support. Vionic prides itself on podiatrist-approved options, no matter the style. Customer review: ‚ÄúThese are a dream come true! I have avoided wearing ballet flats for years because they usually lacked arch support. Vionic for the win...now I can wear them with full support for all day comfort!‚Äù
These charming, feminine flats have a removable PORON¬Æ-cushioned insole that focuses on offering maximum arch support. 
Sizes: 5-11

Material: Polyester, leather
Customer review: ‚ÄúThese are incredibly comfortable. I wore them the first day for 10+ hours and no blisters!‚Äù
The classic black flat gets a sleek update in the form of this pointed-toe cutout style. Not only can you wear these with practically everything, but you‚Äôll also be relieved to know they‚Äôre built with contour and comfort technology, so you can wear them (painlessly) all day long.
Sizes: 5-12
Colors: Black, Hazelnut, Silver
Material: Synthetic
Widths: Standard, Wide
Customer review: ‚ÄúCute, dressy flat. Fits true to size, rubs slightly on my heel...but they are great for dressing up an outfit.‚Äù
These houndstooth slingback flats bring sophisticated details to a classic style‚Äîlike a side cutout, oversized buckle, and a cushioned footbed with arch support. Perfect for pairing with your favorite sweater and neutral slacks.
Sizes: 5-11
Colors: Black Houndstooth, Tobacco, Brown, Black
Material: Leather, synthetic, rubber
Customer review: ‚ÄúThese shoes are beautiful! True to size fit and well made. I had read some reviews that said these shoes run small...this is not my experience. I may get another pair!‚Äù
FitFlop burst onto the footwear scene in 2007 when they introduced biomechanically engineered sandals designed to complement ‚Äúbody structure, joint alignment and natural movement,‚Äù while still being non-ugly, of course. A hefty feat indeed, but they‚Äôve overwhelmingly succeeded and expanded their footwear styles to include sneakers, boots, and flats‚Äîlike this one with almost 300 5-star Amazon reviews.
Sizes: 5-11
Colors: 19 options
Material: Leather, fabric, rubber
Customer review: ‚ÄúThese were perfect...they fit so well they feel like slippers, especially with the subtly padded insole & cushioned outsole...they look like flats but have nice arch support.‚Äù
Typically, actual ballet dancers have notoriously high arches in their feet. But arch support-specific shoes are usually best for lower arch, or flatter, feet. 
‚ÄúHigher arch feet usually need more cushioning in the shoes for shock absorption than arch support, so I usually do not recommend an arch support shoe for these patients,‚Äù Anderson says. Whether your arches are high or low, you should always consult your doctor before ditching all your shoes for orthotics. If your feet are too flat, arch support can cause pesky callouses from excessive pressure along the arch. In this case, it‚Äôs best to seek out a custom orthotic that fits your shoes. 
‚ÄúBallet can be very hard on your feet,‚Äù Anderson notes, due to years of stretching and strengthening the midsole to stand on pointe. But ballet flats in general are ‚Äúnot considered a supportive shoe because they lack significant shoe structure, they have a narrow toe-box, and have no support for the foot,‚Äù she states. And a super thin flat with no support can make you feel like your feet are literally pounding the pavement all day long.
To counteract this, Anderson advises looking for flats that specifically tout arch support or a heel cup, and a wider toe-box to allow for more wiggle room in the shoes. However, if you do have severe podiatric woes, you may want to wear the style carefully. ‚ÄúI will caution that ballet flats are usually not as deep as other shoes, and this can lead to nail injury due to excessive pressure on the nails,‚Äù Anderson warns.

title: The 25 Best ‚ÄòSex and the City‚Äô Guest Stars
text:
I couldn't help but wonder, who hasn't been on SATC?
For six seasons, Sex and the City was a revolving door for actors and actresses who were either fans of the show, friends of the show, or up-and-comers who just wanted to be part of the action. Some played versions of themselves (Matthew McConaughey, Lucy Liu), while others were barely recognizable (a young Kat Dennings, Andy Cohen). Here, a look back at some of the famous faces who crossed paths with Carrie, Samantha, Miranda, and Charlotte over the years.
All episodes are available to stream on Max
Jack (Bradley Cooper) was bad news from the beginning. As Carrie says in the episode, "They Shoot Single People, Don't They?" Jack was everything she needed at 2 a.m. on a Tuesday at a gay bar: single, straight, smoker. It could've been the greasy hair, the tempting smoking habit (she was trying really hard to quit), or the fact that Jack later discovered Carrie's "Single & Fabulous?" New York Magazine cover story ‚Äî the two never did anything more than make out in a crowded bar and briefly, in his convertible. 
In ‚ÄúThe Perfect Present,‚Äù Carrie, Samantha, Charlotte, and Miranda head to a purse party thrown by the recently dumped Vanessa, played by the queen of the bend-and-snap. ‚ÄúIsn‚Äôt life funny? Because of that fucker, I‚Äôve discovered, I‚Äôm Fendi!‚Äù she says in the episode, moments before walking into Samantha and Smith (in his pre-Gus Van Sant days) boning against several glass racks. 
Geri Halliwell played Phoebe, someone Samantha runs into on one of the hottest days of the summer. While fanning herself, Samantha learns (via Phoebe) that the pool at Soho House is the place to be, that is, if you can get past the waiting list. Enter: Annabelle Bronstein, whose membership card Samantha finds in the bathroom and uses a few times before her jig is up.
Between the end of The X-Files (the OG run) and the beginning of Californication, David Duchovny guest starred on several TV shows including Sex and the City. He played Jeremy, Carrie‚Äôs high school boyfriend (sorry, "sweetheart") who completely sweeps her off her feet before revealing he‚Äôs starting treatment at a mental institution in Connecticut. Here he is welcoming Carrie to the Juneau Spears Center, a place harder to get into (and out) of than the Soho House.
Justin Theroux had the distinct honor of guest starring on SATC twice. On the season one episode, ‚ÄúThe Monogamists,‚Äù Justin played Jared, a writer friend of Stanford‚Äôs who had a thing for giving the thumbs-up and was named one of  New York Magazine‚Äôs ‚Äú30 Coolest People Under 30.‚Äù His character didn‚Äôt venture too far in the occupation department the second time around; on the season two episode ‚ÄúShortcomings,‚Äù Justin played Vaughn, a fiction writer who orgasms too fast (hence, the episode‚Äôs title). 
In the same episode where Samantha famously said, ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt believe in the Republican party or the Democratic party; I believe in parties,‚Äù Elizabeth Banks checked off one of her very first TV roles. In ‚ÄúPolitically Erect,‚Äù Elizabeth played Catherine, the pearl-wearing fianc√©e of a politician Charlotte had set her eyes on at a fundraiser. According to Catherine, she met Bob, the fianc√©e, at a party where women brought guys they didn't want to date, leading a martini-filled Charlotte to mumble something about one women's trash becoming another's treasure.
John Slattery played politician Bill Kelley, who was running for city treasurer and famously told Carrie, "I love making love with you," before asking her to pee on him in the shower. When Carrie offered to "dribble warm tea" on him instead, Bill dumped her, citing that his campaign advisors didn't like her sex column. This of course, led Carrie to write a bit called, "To Pee or Not To Pee?" without using his real name. "It was much more political not to," she said on the episode.
Reason #2409 why you should never date someone you meet at your therapist‚Äôs office: Seth, played by Jon Bon Jovi in ‚ÄúGames People Play.‚Äù In the episode, Seth takes Carrie out to dinner, plays a sexy game of Twister, and tells her he‚Äôs in therapy because he‚Äôs ‚Äúreally fucked up about women‚Ä¶ after I sleep with them I lose interest‚Äù ‚Äî after sleeping with Carrie.
Remember when Samantha used Lucy Liu‚Äôs name for a Birkin bag that had a 5-year waiting list? On ‚ÄúCoulda, Woulda, Shoulda,‚Äù Samantha committed this very crime ‚Äì a travesty in the PR world ‚Äì and got caught by Lucy, who played herself on the episode.
In the L.A.-set episode, appropriately titled "Escape From New York," SMG played Debbie, the "most ambitious and feared creature," according to Carrie. Debbie was a junior development executive who really, really wanted to make a movie out of Carrie's columns. She also predicted that the movie would be "chick flick big" before declaring that the man who came up with that term "should have his balls cut off."
In the same L.A. episode as SMG, Matthew McConaughey played a hyper version of himself who was interested in Carrie's movie and her columns. In a cringe-worthy business meeting, the SATC version of Matthew declared that he wanted to play Mr. Big and sleep with Carrie, all while biting on a toothpick. "We are animals, men, women, walking the earth," he said in this scene. "We are made of head, heart, and loins. We're talking about using them, am I right?" Nah. Carrie was good, which is why she GTFO of there.

Before she was Bailey on Grey‚Äôs Anatomy, Chandra Wilson played a cop who confronted Samantha about her Richard ‚ÄúCHEATER‚Äù posters in the episode titled "Anchors Away." When Samantha explained, ‚ÄúThis man said he loved me, and I caught him eating another woman‚Äôs pussy,‚Äù the extremely understanding cop backed off in full support of this public shaming.
Carrie‚Äôs columns never did turn into a movie, but they did turn into a book thanks to the brains of Lily Martin, book agent, played by Molly Shannon. Together with Courtney Masterson (Amy Sedaris; see next slide), Lily transformed Carrie's words  into something with a spine. At their first meeting, Lily got right to the point: ‚ÄúIs it hopeful? What's the message? What‚Äôs your point of view, after all the break ups and disappointments and train wrecks? You still believe he‚Äôs out there, right?‚Äù That gasp you heard? Millions of people asking why after all these years, Lily still knows what they‚Äôre thinking. 
When she was not finishing Lily‚Äôs sentences, Courtney (Amy Sedaris) was busy introducing future lovers to each other. Case in point: Carrie and Berger, who met while Carrie was in a book meeting with Courtney at her office. Hard to believe this relationship eventually ended with a Post-it note by way of The Hamptons, motorcycle rides, and a white noise machine that only took Carrie to the rainforest.
Before he was Tag on Friends, Eddie Cahill played Sean, Carrie‚Äôs bisexual ‚Äúgeneration-something else‚Äù fling that she met at a party celebrating his ‚Äúinternet magazine‚Ä¶ that I still couldn‚Äôt find on my computer.‚Äù Carrie Bradshaw and her internet talk! Despite the fact that they had a great time on her ice skating date (she smoked and drank on the ice like a rebellious young!) Carrie was not prepared for where he took her to next: a party attended by the next SATC guest star on this list...
... Alanis! On "Boy, Girl, Boy Girl.." the Canadian singer played Dawn, who kisses Carrie in a game of spin the bottle. Following the experience, which "wasn't bad, kind of like chicken," Carrie went home and confirmed that she was indeed  "too old to play this game." Other than Carrie's giant flower brooch (which of course got an update in one of the movies), this kiss was a shining moment for the episode.
To give back, Charlotte volunteered to be a guide for the blind on season six. Part of her training required walking in public with a mask and a guide to experience what the blind experience. Enter: Carrie, who fails miserably as Charlotte's guide. I guess this is why you shouldn't perform these training exercises at a Barneys, especially with stellar shoe salesmen like this one, played by SJP's real-life BFF Andy Cohen, around.
There was no one better than Kat Dennings for the role of Jenny Brier, a bratty, lip-gloss wearing 13-year-old who asks Samantha to plan her Bat Mitzvah on season three. When Samantha hesitates, Jenny name drops Carson Daly and "The Clintons" (who "of course can't make it") before casually revealing her bank account: "We'd be lucky if we can swing this for under a mil." To which Samantha responds, "We'll never get *NSYNC."
On an episode titled "Easy Come, Easy Go," Samantha has a fling with Adam, a director who has well, funky spunk. When he says she's just trying to avoid blowjobs and that they're "easy," Samantha, arguably the best sex-ed teacher (and life coach) on TV, launches into one of the most memorable SATC speeches: "I love giving head. Easy? You men have no idea what we're dealing with down there. Teeth placement, jaw stress, suction, gag reflex, all the while bobbing up and down trying to breathe through our noses. Easy? Honey, they don't call it a job for nothing." Mic. Drop.
On season four, Margaret Cho played Lynne, a fashion show producer who recruits Carrie to walk in a show that features New Yorkers and models alike. ‚ÄúNo one is more New York or has more style than you,‚Äù she says on the episode, ‚ÄúThe Real Me.‚Äù When Carrie hesitates, Lynne delivers another convincing command: ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre fucking doing my show. If I have to hunt you down, skin you alive, and have one of the models fucking wear you.‚Äù The only problem with this character was that there was not enough of her. Imagine her having a showdown with Samantha?
Peggy is Cosmopolitan.com‚Äôs entertainment writer, specializing in Leonardo DiCaprio, This Is Us, and the royals. She‚Äôs also a proud Canadian and pug lover. When Peggy‚Äôs not obsessing over Leo‚Äôs latest lover or gut size, she can be found watching old episodes of Friends or Gilmore Girls. Her dream is to one day live on a pug farm and write children‚Äôs books, with illustrations by her very talented husband Greg.

title: 65 Vintage Photos of Old Hollywood Stars on Their Honeymoon
text:
Including Eddie Fisher and Debbie Reynolds's nautical getaway. 
Marrying the love of your life shouldn't be followed by any old vacation‚Äîespecially when you're a celebrity who is used to the glitz and glamour that comes with stardom. And while some of these famous marriages eventually ended in heartache‚Äîand often dramatic, messy divorces‚Äîthat doesn't mean we shouldn't look back at the happy times. Here, rare photos offer a peek inside the most lavish Old Hollywood honeymoons, from Elizabeth Taylor and Eddie Fisher's Italian escape to Marilyn Monroe and Joe DiMaggio's Japanese getaway.
Two of the most talked-about stars of the '20s, Pickford and Fairbanks, travel by ship on their European honeymoon. Here, they are docked in London.
Lord Mountbatten‚Äîa.k.a. Prince Philip's uncle‚Äîand his bride Edwina head to New York for their honeymoon aboard an ocean liner called Majestic.
Queen Elizabeth's parents, Prince Albert and Elizabeth Bowes-Lyon (later King George VI and Queen Elizabeth the Queen Mother, respectively) were married in 1923. They honeymooned in Polesden Lacy, an estate in Great Bookham, England.
Suitcase in hand, the American screen star and his actress wife arrive in Rome for their honeymoon. They got married on February 9 in London.
The movie stars relax on a Santa Monica beach just a few months after their October 1933 nuptials. 
Four decades before he was President, Reagan was an actor and married future Academy Award-winner Jane Wyman. Here, they play ping pong at the El Mirador Hotel in Palm Springs.
The actress and artist spent their honeymoon in the White Mountains in New Hampshire, after making a stop in Mexico City for a little R&R first. 
A few years before she took the throne, then-Princess Elizabeth married the Duke of Edinburgh. Here, they walk through the leaves outside the Broadlands Estate, an English country house where they spent their honeymoon.

title: Spring 2024 Makeup Trends We Love from Fashion Week
text:
Fresh off the runway. 
It‚Äôs the most wonderful time of the year‚Äîno, it‚Äôs not the holidays (yet); however, it is a fashion holiday: fashion month. And while you may be eyeing the celebs sitting front row or dreaming of your next outfit, the runway is the perfect place to discover what‚Äôs next in beauty. 
This season, the crystal ball, er, runway, proved that even though we‚Äôre not masking up as frequently (rethink that: Covid cases are rising), eyes are a major focus and using color as a way of expression. Skin is in‚Äîwith fresh faces and dewy skin taking priority on the runway. In fact, this season, many skincare brands, prepped models‚Äô skin for the runway. After all, if you want great looking makeup, you must take care of its base: Your face. Brandon Maxwell leaned into a skin-focused beauty look, utilizing Noble Panacea products for a hydrated, fresh glow. 
Do you want to peek into the future to see what‚Äôs in store for 2024? Katie Jane Hughes, celebrity makeup artist and founder of KJH.brand whose clients include Hailey Bieber and Karlie Kloss as well as Kim Baker, celebrity makeup artist and founder of Glamazon Beauty divulge to ELLE.com all top Spring 2024 makeup trends, fresh off the runway!
Graphic liner, floating eyeliner‚Äîwhatever you want to call it, it‚Äôs a vibe and you will see it all Spring/Summer 2024. This graphic liner look on Paloma Elsesser at Eckhaus Latta gives a butterfly wing effect and plays up her high cheekbones. 
‚ÄúI love how a graphic eye can be an accessory to your look,‚Äù shares Katie Jane Hughes in response to the Jil Sander show at Milan Fashion Week.
Celebrity makeup artist and Lanc√¥me Global International Makeup Artist Sheika Dailey took us to the year 3000 with this futuristic cat eye. Playing with negative space and floating lines in the inner eye, ups the sex appeal of this sultry look. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs editorial yet still super wearable and sexy,‚Äù says Hughes. You can read more about the look, here.
‚ÄúI predict that the Spring/Summer ‚Äô24 makeup trends are going to be all about vibrant, bold, color eyeliners,‚Äù shares Glamazon Beauty founder and celebrity makeup artist Kim Baker. Curious as to which colors? Baker says, ‚ÄúEyeliner in bold over the top shades such as Periwinkle, royal blue, vibrant red, and shocking pink‚Äù will be all over the lids of trendsetters and beauty girlies next spring.
Hughes also agrees that color eyeliner is a big Spring/Summer ‚Äô24 trend. ‚ÄúI love how they matched the eye look to the fashion at Helmut Lang,‚Äù says Hughes. ‚ÄúIn 2024, the vibrant color lined eye will dominate the street and our makeup bag,‚Äù adds Baker.
Don‚Äôt have colored eyeliner? You can fake it with eyeshadow. ‚ÄúWe saw royal blue being used at shows such as Altier Ndigo. Makeup artist T. Cooper used the shade ‚ÄòOshun‚Äô featured in the Supreme Being Palette by Glamazon Beauty to create a killer eye look that works for runway to real-way,‚Äù says Baker.
For Spring/Summer ‚Äô24, imperfection is perfection. And while we normally see this trend with the hair, this season, it‚Äôs visible with makeup in a bold, bright way. The mismatched eyeshadow seen at Chopova Lowena was a favorite for Hughes. She shares, ‚ÄúI think this is a really cool and fresh take on how to do eyeshadow that is unusual and out of the box.‚Äù
At Phillip Lim 3.1, this neon, one shadow look plays up negative space in opposite accords.
‚ÄúThe look I kept seeing across the board was glowing skin. Everyone had dewy, glowing skin and I can‚Äôt think of a better feature to play up for Spring and Summer,‚Äù says Baker. At Retrofete, it was all about sexy, glowy, and hydrated skin. Elyse Reneau, Executive Director of Global Beauty at Too Faced states, ‚ÄúHumidity has never looked so sculpted!‚Äù 
At Altuzurra, celebrity makeup artist Diane Kendal showcased her famous ‚Äúflawless face‚Äù technique that she developed early in her career. It focuses on making skin look as radiant and perfect as possible, using minimal makeup.
Mermaidcore gets an update for Spring/Summer ‚Äô24. At Sandy Liang, rhinestones were placed haphazardly around the eyes to mimic barnacles. Into this look? You can read our full take on it, here.

Jason Wu‚Äôs interpretation highlights healthy skin. ‚ÄúInspired by Jason‚Äôs vision of experiencing rebirth after a shipwreck, we crafted a cohesive makeup look that exuded a dewy, aquatic allure,‚Äù shares Kendal, who was the Lead Makeup Artist. Wu‚Äôs Kindness For Your Lips Lip Oil was applied on the high cheekbones for a luminous glow.

Eager to have luscious locks? Look no further. 
There‚Äôs nothing more upsetting than looking in the mirror and noticing sparse areas of hair on your scalp‚Äî dare we say bald spots. For those of you who have dealt with hair loss or hair thinning, you've probably gone down a rabbit hole of research, attempting to discover the best ways to restore your beloved strands. While desperately scouring the internet for answers, we're guessing that you came across a variety of hair growth shampoos and hair growth oils . And perhaps you found a thing or two about collagen.
On a basic level, collagen is one of the most abundant structural proteins found in the body. Composed of several types of amino acids, this powerful protein helps to promote skin elasticity, support muscular health, and encourage hair growth. ‚ÄúThe most abundant amino acids in collagen are glycine, proline, hydroxyproline, and arginine, which are crucial for maintaining the health, elasticity, and strength of skin and hair,‚Äù says Dr. Dusan Sajic, board certified dermatologist. Thus, it comes as no surprise that many of us rely on collagen supplements to foster thriving hair.  
Consuming collagen supplements can be a great after-the-fact solution, but it should also be considered as a preventative measure, especially as we get older.  ‚ÄúAs we age, not only do we produce less collagen, we also lose excessive collagen due to environmental stressors like UV exposure, smoke exposure, and poor health habits,‚Äù says Shannon Augustine, board certified aesthetic nurse practitioner. But fear not, because luckily, there are plenty of collagen supplements that exist‚Äî from capsules to powders, and even liquids. Ahead, we‚Äôve curated a list of the best collagen products for hair growth and we've also consulted medical and cosmetic dermatologist Dr. Dusan Sajic as well as aesthetic nurse practicioner Shannon Augustine, who have shared everything you need to know about collagen.

Dr. Sajic tells ELLE.com that collagen is a protein formulated with amino acids that provide structure, elasticity, and strength to both skin and hair. ‚ÄúAltogether around fifty-six percent or more of the amino acids in collagen are foundational for skin and hair proteins, and thus has a great ratio that will contribute directly to hair health and vitality,‚Äù Dr. Sajic explains. 
However, it‚Äôs essential to understand that while collagen can certainly help to solve some of your hair problems, maintaining a healthy diet is equally important. ‚ÄúOptimal hair health also requires a more comprehensive approach, including other proteins, vitamins, minerals, and care practices,‚Äù Dr. Sajic says. 
Although collagen is widely recognized for its ability to promote healthy hair and skin, this abundant protein also plays a crucial role in other bodily functions including joint health and bone health. ‚ÄúCollagen assists in maintaining the integrity of cartilage, which is essential for healthy joints, and it helps to maintain bone density, which is crucial for preventing age-related bone issues like osteoporosis,‚Äù Dr. Sajic explains. 
If you‚Äôre looking to target these areas of your body, or simply interested in a supplement that provides a cohesive approach, it‚Äôs worth incorporating collagen supplements into your daily wellness routine. 
Also to note, some collagen supplements are infused with additional nutrients that help to nourish the body. ‚ÄúCollagen supplements may also include vitamins like vitamin C, zinc, vitamin B, and omega-3s which further support your body and health,‚Äù Augustine says. 
So, we‚Äôve heard about all the wonderful benefits of collagen but are there any side effects? Dr. Sajic shares that although collagen is generally safe for most individuals, there are a few things to note. ‚ÄúSome may experience side effects like stomach discomfort, a bad taste or possible allergic reactions,‚Äù Dr. Sajic says. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs essential to choose high-quality collagen supplements and consult with a healthcare provider before starting any new supplement regimen,‚Äù he adds.
To avoid allergic reactions, or any added ingredients that might not sit well with your body, Augustine also suggests taking the time to thoroughly read the ingredient labels.  
‚ÄúYou should always talk to your health care provider before taking any oral supplements or medications,‚Äù says Augustine. She also explains that consulting a healthcare professional is especially important if you are taking daily medications or have serious drug or food allergies.
Dr. Sajic shares that those with fish, pork, or bovine allergies should avoid collagen, as many collagen supplements are derived from these animal sources. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs also important to talk to your doctor if you have liver or kidney disease, as the excess protein may put extra stress on these organs,‚Äù he adds. 
Collagen supplements exist in many forms‚Äî including liquid, powder, and capsules‚Äî but they all have relatively equal effects. "There are not enough non-bias studies to suggest that one is better than the other,‚Äù Augustine shares. 
At the end of the day, it simply boils down to your personal preferences, lifestyle, and dietary restrictions. ‚ÄúLiquid collagen can be consumed directly or mixed into beverages, while powder can be added to smoothies, coffee, or baked goods,‚Äù Dr. Sajic says. If you would prefer not to mix collagen with your food or drink, you can always take a capsule. However, Dr. Sajic notes that depending on the capsule, it might not be absorbed as efficiently as other forms of collagen. 
‚ÄúFor most people, collagen should be taken once daily,‚Äù Dr. Sajic says. ‚ÄúDosage can range from 2.5 to 15 grams daily, depending on the individual‚Äôs age, health, and specific skin or hair concerns.‚Äù And as with anything, patience and consistency is key, so make sure that you keep track of your collagen intake. ‚ÄúIt may take several weeks, if not three to four months, for you to start noticing the benefits of collagen supplements,‚Äù Dr. Sajic adds.

Created by the brand that brought us the chicest, most enviable lingerie in the market, the perfumes by La Perla are just as desirable. This scent is citrusy enough to invoke a bold, wide-awake feeling, but countered with dark notes of neroli, too.
A Nordstrom reviewer says: ‚ÄúVery beautiful, fruity violet perfume. This smells like a rich French woman. Oozes elegance, and the bottle is just oh-my-god stunning.‚Äù
Smells like: A floral boutique
Key notes: Jasmine, rose essence, chypre accord
With ambassador Zendaya as its leading lady, Lancome‚Äôs Idole already has a lot going for it. But with its burst of fresh florals‚Äîrose and jasmine, in particular‚Äîthis makes for a fully feminine, but never overpowering, scent.
An Amazon reviewer says: ‚ÄúBeautiful scent of flowers that lasts on your clothes and wherever you spray it on yourself for well over a day! Plus, you only need a little bit, because it most certainly goes a long way.‚Äù
Smells like: Spicy amber
Key notes: Jasmine, saffron, cedarwood, ambergris accord 
Baccarat Rouge 540 is another woodsy scent with a sweeter edge. That first whiff is sweet, then it evolves into spicy, earthy notes of jasmine, cedar, and saffron.
‚ÄúThis perfume is a guaranteed conversation starter. The distinct smell either evokes the response of 'Ahh, I love 540,' amongst knowing individuals or 'What is that smell?!' to those that are about to be introduced to the reigning king of the perfume occult. It seems more genderless at first spritz, but then dries down to a sweet, woody, sexy aroma.‚Äù ‚Äî Danielle James, Beauty Director, ELLE.com

Key notes: Ylang ylang, Damascus rose, jasmine
There‚Äôs a reason you see this iconic bottle in practically every magazine you‚Äôve ever opened. It‚Äôs a classic, and the fruity, floral ingredients never weigh down the luscious elegance of the ylang-ylang, jasmine, pear, melon, peach, and lily. 
A Sephora reviewer says: ‚ÄúLovely floral scent, not too warm or heavy but still has good lasting power. Would recommended this to all ages and seems appropriate for both day and night. Gorgeous bottle.‚Äù
Smells like: Early summer morning by a beach
Key notes: Bergamot, pink pepper, primofiore lemon, neroli oil
Even if you don‚Äôt live near the coast, this effervescent summer perfume will instantly transport to warm, sandy shores with notes of bergamot, coconut milk, and aquatic-inspired transluzone. Also, what‚Äôs not to love about its striking apothecary-style bottle? 
A Nordstrom reviewer says: ‚ÄúLove this scent, takes me to holiday in my head in one spritz. All the best bits‚Äîsun cream, salty skin, fruity cocktails, and tropical flowers. Delicious. The scent really lasts well, too. Great for every day!‚Äù
Smells like: Spicy florals
Key notes: Black Coffee, white flowers, vanilla
For those who crave a little danger in their dress-up, this sexy concoction smelling of coffee, vanilla, and pear is a feast for the senses. A little smooth, a little edgy, this is a fantastic fragrance for evening wear.
A Sephora reviewer says: ‚ÄúOne of my favorite scents. Very mature but not like an old lady scent. It‚Äôs sophisticated and warm. I wear this year-round but suggest wearing it in the winter.‚Äù
Smells like: First bloom of spring flowers
Key notes: Bergamot, lychee, peach, jasmine, peony, orange blossom, moss, musk
This luxurious and fruity perfume is like summer in a bottle. Featuring unique traces of lychee, peony, orange blossom, and peach, with a little musk mixed in for good measure, this is like a well-made cocktail‚Äîworth the extra cost. 
A Saks Fifth Avenue reviewer says: ‚ÄúAs a perfume hoarder, I can say that I have nothing like it in my collection, and it smells amazing! It‚Äôs a citrusy floral that settles in very beautifully.‚Äù
Smells like: Fancy flowers
Key notes: Calypso orchid, mandarin, Bulgarian rose, almond milk, ylang ylang, iris, white musks, sandalwood
Buckle up tight because this fragrance takes you on a ride. The yin-yang scent composition unfurls a delicate composition of sensual citrus and florals, then comes the dip: warm almond milk, sandalwood, and white musk.
‚ÄúAs someone with over 100 fragrances, my signature scent changes daily. However, I almost always begin most of my scent layers with Yin Transformation, which bursts with creamy florals that feel like a balmy spring morning.‚Äù ‚Äî NP
Smells like: Freshly squeeze berries over florals
Key notes: Schisandra berry, mulberry, lily of the valley, plum blossom, honeysuckle, white amber, sandalwood, musk
Drawing inspiration from the Korean word songari, which means an array of flowers or fruit on a single stem, this enticing fragrance is at once familiar and unexpected. Top notes of mulberry and Korea-native Schisandra berry open up to plum blossom and honeysuckle, followed by subtly grounding base notes of amber and sandalwood.
‚ÄúElorea‚Äôs genderless perfumes are quickly becoming some of my new favorites. The burgeoning K-beauty brand looks to nature and its founders‚Äô shared heritage to create some undeniably divine scents, like the soft yet not overly sweet Inflorescence. If you‚Äôre unsure which Elorea perfumes will best suit you, I also love that the label offers a discovery set, which comes with a voucher of equal value that can be applied to any purchase of a full-sized scent.‚Äù‚ÄîSam Peters, ELLE.com contributor

Key notes: Black pepper, raspberry accord, peony accord, geranium, freesia accord, Turkish rose, patchouli, musk
If all you want for your birthday is a bushel of peonies, this perfume should be a runner-up. It‚Äôs a beautiful floral fragrance with notes of raspberry, geranium, Turkish rose, and peony. Basically a wearable bouquet.
A Nordstrom reviewer says: ‚ÄúThis is a lovely perfume with so many enticing scents‚Äìuplifting citrus, woodiness, and unusual florals. I found this to be really lovely, with good staying power.‚Äù
